Python.name: Requests
Python.description: Requests is an elegant and simple HTTP library for Python, designed to make sending HTTP/1.1 requests easy and human-friendly. It abstracts the complexities of handling HTTP connections, cookies, headers, and authentication.
Python.story: Requests was created by Kenneth Reitz in 2011 to simplify HTTP requests in Python. Its goal was to provide a more readable and intuitive API compared to urllib and urllib2. Over the years, it became one of the most widely used Python libraries for web interactions, API clients, and automation tasks.

usage.overview: Requests allows you to send HTTP/1.1 requests using methods such as GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, HEAD, and OPTIONS. You can pass parameters, headers, JSON payloads, handle cookies, manage sessions, and handle authentication easily.

basic_examples.title: Simple GET request
basic_examples.code:
import requests
response = requests.get('https://httpbin.org/get')
print(response.status_code)
print(response.json())
basic_examples.explanation: This example performs a GET request to a URL and prints the HTTP status code and JSON response.

basic_examples.title: POST request with JSON payload
basic_examples.code:
import requests
payload = {'key':'value'}
response = requests.post('https://httpbin.org/post', json=payload)
print(response.json())
basic_examples.explanation: Sends a POST request with a JSON payload to the specified URL.

advanced_examples.title: Session handling
advanced_examples.code:
import requests
session = requests.Session()
session.get('https://httpbin.org/cookies/set/sessioncookie/123456789')
response = session.get('https://httpbin.org/cookies')
print(response.text)
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses a Session object to persist cookies and headers across multiple requests.

advanced_examples.title: Custom headers
advanced_examples.code:
import requests
headers = {'User-Agent': 'my-app/0.0.1'}
response = requests.get('https://httpbin.org/headers', headers=headers)
print(response.json())
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows how to send custom HTTP headers with a request.

advanced_examples.title: Timeouts and retries
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates handling of request timeouts.

error_handling.solution: Use the timeout parameter in requests.get/post to prevent indefinite waiting.
Check network connectivity or use retry mechanisms for robustness.
Call response.raise_for_status() to catch HTTP errors like 4xx or 5xx.

Python.name: Flask
Python.description: Flask is a lightweight and micro web framework for Python, ideal for building small to medium-sized web applications and APIs. It provides the essential tools for web development without imposing a specific project structure, giving developers flexibility and simplicity.
Python.story: Flask was created by Armin Ronacher in 2010 as part of the Pocoo project. It was designed to provide a minimal yet extensible web framework that doesn’t force particular dependencies or structure. Flask emphasizes simplicity, readability, and freedom of choice, making it a popular choice for web apps, APIs, and rapid prototyping.

usage.overview: Flask allows you to define routes, request handlers, templates, and more. It supports RESTful routing, URL parameters, sessions, cookies, and templating via Jinja2. You can build APIs, web services, or full-fledged web applications with ease.

basic_examples.title: Simple Hello World App
basic_examples.explanation: This example creates a basic Flask app with a single route `/`. Running this file starts a local server on port 5000 with debug mode enabled.

basic_examples.title: Using URL Parameters
basic_examples.explanation: Flask supports dynamic URL parameters. Here, `<username>` is captured from the URL and passed to the `greet_user` function.

advanced_examples.title: JSON Responses
advanced_examples.explanation: Use `jsonify` to return JSON responses, suitable for building APIs.

advanced_examples.title: Handling POST Requests
advanced_examples.explanation: Handle POST requests and access JSON data from `request.json`.

advanced_examples.title: Using Templates
advanced_examples.explanation: Flask integrates with Jinja2 templates. `render_template` renders HTML templates with variables.

best_practices: Organize your app into blueprints for modularity.
Use environment variables for configuration (Flask config object).
Enable debug mode only in development.
Validate user inputs to prevent injection attacks.
Use Flask extensions for added functionality (Flask-Login, Flask-Migrate, etc.).

error_handling.solution: Use `@app.errorhandler(404)` to define a custom handler for missing routes.
Use `@app.errorhandler(500)` to catch unhandled exceptions and log them.

Python.name: FastAPI
Python.description: FastAPI is a modern, high-performance Python web framework for building APIs with automatic interactive documentation, leveraging Python type hints for data validation and serialization.
Python.story: FastAPI was created by Sebastián Ramírez in 2018. Its goal was to provide a framework that is fast (high-performance), easy to use, and fully compatible with modern Python features like type hints and async programming. It automatically generates OpenAPI and Swagger documentation for your APIs, making it a popular choice for building RESTful services and microservices.

usage.overview: FastAPI allows you to define API endpoints using Python function definitions with type annotations. It supports async operations, request validation, automatic docs generation, dependency injection, security, and more.

basic_examples.title: Simple GET endpoint
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a GET endpoint at /items/{id}. The 'id' parameter is type-checked as an integer automatically.

basic_examples.title: POST endpoint with JSON body
basic_examples.code:
from fastapi import FastAPI
from pydantic import BaseModel

app = FastAPI()

class Item(BaseModel):
    name: str
    price: float

@app.post('/items/')
async def create_item(item: Item):
    return item
basic_examples.explanation: FastAPI uses Pydantic models to validate and parse JSON request bodies.

advanced_examples.title: Query parameters with validation
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a query parameter 'q' with minimum and maximum length validation.

advanced_examples.title: Path parameters with type enforcement
advanced_examples.explanation: Ensures the user_id path parameter is an integer.

advanced_examples.title: Automatic interactive API docs
advanced_examples.code:
# Run your FastAPI app using uvicorn:
# uvicorn main:app --reload
advanced_examples.explanation: Once running, visit /docs for Swagger UI or /redoc for ReDoc-generated API docs.

advanced_examples.title: Dependency injection
advanced_examples.explanation: Allows reusing common parameters and logic across endpoints.

best_practices: Use Pydantic models for request validation and response models.
Leverage async endpoints for IO-bound operations.
Use dependency injection for reusable logic like authentication or DB connections.
Keep path and query parameters explicit for clarity.
Include meaningful tags and summaries for better auto-generated documentation.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when request body validation fails. Ensure JSON fields match Pydantic model types.
Use proper path parameters and raise HTTPException with status_code=404 when resources are missing.

Python.name: Django
Python.description: Django is a high-level Python web framework that encourages rapid development and clean, pragmatic design. It includes built-in tools for database ORM, authentication, templating, routing, and an admin interface.
Python.story: Django was created by Adrian Holovaty and Simon Willison in 2005 at the Lawrence Journal-World newspaper. Its goal was to simplify web development by providing reusable components and a 'batteries-included' philosophy. Over time, it became one of the most widely used Python frameworks for building scalable, secure web applications.

usage.overview: Django enables developers to quickly create web applications with structured models, views, templates, and URLs. It provides an admin interface out-of-the-box and includes features like authentication, sessions, forms, and security mechanisms.

basic_examples.title: Creating a new project
basic_examples.code:
# Terminal commands
django-admin startproject mysite
cd mysite
python manage.py runserver
basic_examples.explanation: Starts a new Django project named 'mysite'. Running the server starts a local development server at http://127.0.0.1:8000/.

basic_examples.title: Creating a new app
basic_examples.code:
# Terminal commands
python manage.py startapp blog
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a new Django app called 'blog' inside your project. Apps encapsulate related models, views, and templates.

advanced_examples.title: Defining models and migrations
advanced_examples.code:
from django.db import models

class Post(models.Model):
    title = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    content = models.TextField()
    created_at = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a Post model. Use `python manage.py makemigrations` and `python manage.py migrate` to create the database schema.

advanced_examples.title: Views and URL routing
advanced_examples.code:
from django.shortcuts import render
from django.urls import path

# views.py
def home(request):
    return render(request, 'home.html')

# urls.py
urlpatterns = [path('', home, name='home')]
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a view function `home` and maps it to the root URL. Django uses URLconf to connect URLs to views.

advanced_examples.title: Using the Django Admin Interface
advanced_examples.code:
# Register model in admin.py
from django.contrib import admin
from .models import Post
admin.site.register(Post)
advanced_examples.explanation: Adds your model to the admin interface so you can manage database records through the built-in web UI.

best_practices: Keep apps modular and reusable.
Use Django's built-in authentication and permission system for security.
Leverage class-based views for complex logic.
Separate settings for development and production.
Use environment variables for sensitive data.

error_handling.solution: Ensure migrations are applied and database is accessible.
Check the template directory settings and file paths.

Python.name: Pandas
Python.description: Pandas is a powerful Python library for data manipulation and analysis. It provides fast, flexible, and expressive data structures such as Series and DataFrame for working with structured data.
Python.story: Pandas was created by Wes McKinney in 2008 to provide a high-performance, user-friendly data analysis tool for Python. It has become the standard library for data manipulation in Python, widely used in data science, finance, research, and analytics.

usage.overview: Pandas allows for easy reading, writing, and manipulation of data from multiple sources including CSV, Excel, SQL databases, and more. You can filter, aggregate, group, pivot, merge, and reshape datasets efficiently.

basic_examples.title: Loading a CSV and viewing data
basic_examples.code:
import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv('data.csv')
print(df.head())
basic_examples.explanation: Reads a CSV file into a DataFrame and displays the first five rows.

basic_examples.title: Selecting columns and rows
basic_examples.code:
print(df['column_name'])
print(df.iloc[0])
basic_examples.explanation: Access columns by name and rows by index.

advanced_examples.title: Filtering and grouping data
advanced_examples.code:
filtered = df[df['age'] > 30]
grouped = filtered.groupby('department').mean()
advanced_examples.explanation: Filter rows based on a condition and then group by a column to calculate mean values.

advanced_examples.title: Merging DataFrames
advanced_examples.code: merged = pd.merge(df1, df2, on='id', how='inner')
advanced_examples.explanation: Combine two DataFrames on a common column using an inner join.

advanced_examples.title: Pivot tables
advanced_examples.code: pivot = df.pivot_table(index='department', columns='gender', values='salary', aggfunc='mean')
advanced_examples.explanation: Create a pivot table to summarize data efficiently.

best_practices: Use vectorized operations instead of loops for performance.
Clean data before analysis: handle missing values, duplicates, and inconsistent types.
Use descriptive column names for readability.
Leverage built-in aggregation functions for efficiency.
Profile large datasets with df.info() and df.describe() before processing.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the file path is correct when reading CSV/Excel files.
Verify column names exist before accessing them.
Check the shape and alignment of DataFrames when merging or concatenating.

Python.name: NumPy
Python.description: NumPy is a fundamental package for scientific computing in Python. It provides powerful n-dimensional array objects, vectorized operations, linear algebra functions, random number capabilities, and integration with C/C++ and Fortran code.
Python.story: NumPy was created in 2005 by Travis Oliphant as an evolution of the older Numeric and Numarray libraries. It standardized array computing in Python and became the backbone of the Python scientific computing ecosystem, enabling high-performance numerical computations.

usage.overview: NumPy provides ndarray, a multidimensional array object, and functions for fast operations on arrays. It supports element-wise operations, broadcasting, linear algebra, statistical functions, random sampling, and more.

basic_examples.title: Creating arrays and basic operations
basic_examples.code:
import numpy as np
arr = np.array([1,2,3])
print(arr + 1)
print(arr * 2)
basic_examples.explanation: Create a 1D array and perform element-wise addition and multiplication.

basic_examples.title: 2D arrays and matrix multiplication
basic_examples.code:
import numpy as np
A = np.array([[1,2],[3,4]])
B = np.array([[5,6],[7,8]])
print(A @ B)
basic_examples.explanation: Create 2x2 matrices and perform matrix multiplication using the @ operator.

advanced_examples.title: Broadcasting example
advanced_examples.code:
import numpy as np
arr = np.array([[1,2,3],[4,5,6]])
print(arr + np.array([10,20,30]))
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates broadcasting: the 1D array is automatically expanded to match the 2D array for element-wise addition.

advanced_examples.title: Statistical functions
advanced_examples.code:
import numpy as np
arr = np.array([1,2,3,4,5])
print(np.mean(arr))
print(np.std(arr))
advanced_examples.explanation: Compute mean and standard deviation of a numeric array.

advanced_examples.title: Random sampling
advanced_examples.code:
import numpy as np
rand_arr = np.random.randn(3,3)
print(rand_arr)
advanced_examples.explanation: Generate a 3x3 array of samples from a standard normal distribution.

advanced_examples.title: Linear algebra operations
advanced_examples.code:
import numpy as np
A = np.array([[1,2],[3,4]])
print(np.linalg.inv(A))
print(np.linalg.eig(A))
advanced_examples.explanation: Compute the inverse and eigenvalues/eigenvectors of a square matrix.

best_practices: Use vectorized operations instead of Python loops for performance.
Leverage broadcasting for efficient computation on arrays of different shapes.
Prefer NumPy functions over manual Python calculations for large datasets.
Be mindful of array shapes and memory layout (C-contiguous vs F-contiguous).
Use NumPy random functions with fixed seeds for reproducibility in experiments.

error_handling.solution: Check that matrix dimensions match when performing dot products or matrix multiplication.
Ensure array indices are within valid dimensions.
Verify that arrays have compatible numeric types for operations.

Python.name: SciPy
Python.description: SciPy is an open-source Python library used for scientific and technical computing. It builds on NumPy arrays and provides a wide range of algorithms for optimization, integration, interpolation, eigenvalue problems, algebraic equations, differential equations, and signal processing.
Python.story: SciPy was initially created in 2001 by Travis Oliphant, Eric Jones, and Pearu Peterson. It was designed to extend NumPy’s capabilities by providing high-level functions for scientific computations. SciPy has since become a core library in the Python scientific ecosystem and is widely used in engineering, physics, machine learning, and data analysis.

usage.overview: SciPy provides modules for optimization, linear algebra, signal and image processing, statistics, integration, and more. It integrates seamlessly with NumPy arrays and allows advanced scientific computations with minimal code.

basic_examples.title: Minimizing a function
basic_examples.code:
from scipy import optimize
f = lambda x: (x - 3)**2
result = optimize.minimize(lambda v: f(v[0]), x0=[0])
print(result)
basic_examples.explanation: Demonstrates minimizing a simple quadratic function using SciPy's `optimize.minimize` function.

basic_examples.title: Computing definite integrals
basic_examples.code:
from scipy import integrate
result, error = integrate.quad(lambda x: x**2, 0, 1)
print(result)
basic_examples.explanation: Uses `integrate.quad` to compute the definite integral of x² from 0 to 1.

advanced_examples.title: Solving linear systems
advanced_examples.code:
from scipy import linalg
import numpy as np
A = np.array([[3,2],[1,2]])
b = np.array([5,5])
x = linalg.solve(A, b)
print(x)
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses SciPy’s linear algebra module to solve a system of linear equations.

advanced_examples.title: Signal processing example
advanced_examples.code:
from scipy import signal
import numpy as np
b, a = signal.butter(3, 0.05)
z = signal.lfilter(b, a, np.random.randn(1000))
print(z[:10])
advanced_examples.explanation: Designs a 3rd-order Butterworth filter and applies it to a random signal using `signal.lfilter`.

advanced_examples.title: Interpolation example
advanced_examples.code:
from scipy import interpolate
import numpy as np
x = np.arange(5)
y = np.sin(x)
f = interpolate.interp1d(x, y)
print(f(2.5))
advanced_examples.explanation: Performs linear interpolation between data points using SciPy’s `interp1d` function.

best_practices: Use NumPy arrays for input data to ensure compatibility with SciPy functions.
Check function domains and constraints when using optimization routines.
Leverage built-in documentation for each submodule to understand parameter options.
Use `scipy.constants` for physical constants to improve code readability and accuracy.
Profile computations for large datasets using vectorized operations rather than loops.

error_handling.solution: Ensure inputs have correct shapes and types expected by the function.
Check that matrices are square and non-singular when performing linear algebra operations.

Python.name: Matplotlib
Python.description: Matplotlib is a comprehensive 2D plotting library for Python. It allows the creation of high-quality graphs, charts, and figures in various formats, suitable for publication and interactive visualization.
Python.story: Matplotlib was originally created by John D. Hunter in 2003 to provide a MATLAB-like plotting interface for Python. It has become the foundation for many Python visualization libraries, including Seaborn and Pandas plotting utilities, and remains widely used in data analysis, scientific research, and machine learning.

usage.overview: Matplotlib allows you to create line plots, scatter plots, bar charts, histograms, 3D plots, and more. The library provides both an object-oriented interface and a state-based interface (pyplot) to build plots programmatically or interactively.

basic_examples.title: Simple Line Plot
basic_examples.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.plot([1, 2, 3], [2, 3, 5])
plt.xlabel('X-axis')
plt.ylabel('Y-axis')
plt.title('Simple Line Plot')
plt.show()
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a basic line plot with labeled axes and a title.

basic_examples.title: Scatter Plot
basic_examples.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
x = [1, 2, 3, 4]
y = [10, 20, 25, 30]
plt.scatter(x, y, color='red', marker='x')
plt.show()
basic_examples.explanation: Generates a scatter plot with custom color and marker type.

advanced_examples.title: Subplots
advanced_examples.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
fig, axs = plt.subplots(2, 1)
axs[0].plot([1,2,3],[1,4,9])
axs[1].bar([1,2,3],[5,2,7])
plt.show()
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows multiple plots in a single figure using subplots.

advanced_examples.title: Customizing styles
advanced_examples.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.style.use('ggplot')
plt.plot([1,2,3],[1,4,9])
plt.show()
advanced_examples.explanation: Applies a built-in style to enhance visual aesthetics.

advanced_examples.title: 3D Plot
advanced_examples.code:
from mpl_toolkits.mplot3d import Axes3D
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
fig = plt.figure()
ax = fig.add_subplot(111, projection='3d')
x = np.linspace(0,5,100)
y = np.sin(x)
z = np.cos(x)
ax.plot(x,y,z)
plt.show()
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates creating a 3D line plot.

advanced_examples.title: Histogram
advanced_examples.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
data = [1,1,2,3,3,3,4,4,5]
plt.hist(data, bins=5, color='purple', alpha=0.7)
plt.show()
advanced_examples.explanation: Plots a histogram with specified number of bins and styling.

best_practices: Use the object-oriented interface for complex plots for more control.
Label axes and add titles to improve readability.
Use grid lines and legends where appropriate.
Combine Matplotlib with NumPy for efficient data plotting.
Save figures using `plt.savefig()` for reproducibility.

error_handling.error: ValueError: x and y must have same first dimension
error_handling.solution: Ensure your x and y data arrays have the same length.
Install Matplotlib fully and ensure the toolkit is available for 3D plots.

Python.name: Seaborn
Python.description: Seaborn is a Python data visualization library based on Matplotlib that provides a high-level interface for drawing attractive and informative statistical graphics.
Python.story: Seaborn was created by Michael Waskom in 2014 to simplify the creation of complex statistical plots. It integrates closely with Pandas data structures and makes it easy to generate visualizations that include summaries of datasets and categorical relationships.

usage.overview: Seaborn simplifies the process of creating visualizations such as bar plots, box plots, violin plots, heatmaps, and pair plots. It provides aesthetic defaults and works directly with Pandas DataFrames.

basic_examples.title: Simple histogram
basic_examples.code:
import seaborn as sns
sns.histplot([1,1,2,3,5])
basic_examples.explanation: Plots a histogram of the given list of values using Seaborn’s default styling.

basic_examples.title: Scatter plot with regression line
basic_examples.code:
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
df = pd.DataFrame({'x':[1,2,3,4],'y':[2,3,5,7]})
sns.regplot(x='x', y='y', data=df)
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a scatter plot and automatically fits a regression line to the data.

advanced_examples.title: Boxplot for categorical data
advanced_examples.code:
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
df = pd.DataFrame({'category':['A','A','B','B'], 'value':[10,12,20,22]})
sns.boxplot(x='category', y='value', data=df)
advanced_examples.explanation: Visualizes the distribution of values for each category using a boxplot.

advanced_examples.title: Heatmap
advanced_examples.code:
import seaborn as sns
import numpy as np
data = np.random.rand(5,5)
sns.heatmap(data, annot=True, cmap='coolwarm')
advanced_examples.explanation: Creates a heatmap of a 2D dataset with annotations and a custom color map.

advanced_examples.title: Pairplot for relationships
advanced_examples.code:
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
df = sns.load_dataset('iris')
sns.pairplot(df, hue='species')
advanced_examples.explanation: Plots pairwise relationships in a dataset, colored by species.

best_practices: Use Pandas DataFrames for structured data input.
Leverage Seaborn’s built-in themes for visually appealing plots.
Combine with Matplotlib for custom modifications.
Use hue, style, and size parameters to enhance multi-dimensional plots.
Always label axes and provide legends for clarity.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the column names used in the plot match those in the DataFrame.
Install Seaborn using pip or conda before importing.

Python.name: Scikit-learn
Python.description: Scikit-learn is a Python library for machine learning that provides simple and efficient tools for data mining, analysis, and modeling. It includes algorithms for classification, regression, clustering, dimensionality reduction, and model evaluation.
Python.story: Scikit-learn was initially developed by David Cournapeau in 2007 and has since evolved into a widely used open-source machine learning library maintained by a large community. It is built on top of NumPy, SciPy, and Matplotlib, and is widely adopted in both academia and industry for machine learning tasks.

usage.overview: Scikit-learn provides consistent APIs for different machine learning algorithms. You can fit models to data, predict outcomes, evaluate performance, and preprocess datasets with transformers and pipelines.

basic_examples.title: Training a simple classifier
basic_examples.code:
from sklearn.datasets import load_iris
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression

X, y = load_iris(return_X_y=True)
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2)
model = LogisticRegression(max_iter=200)
model.fit(X_train, y_train)
print(model.score(X_test, y_test))
basic_examples.explanation: Loads the Iris dataset, splits it into training and testing sets, trains a logistic regression model, and evaluates accuracy.

basic_examples.title: K-Means clustering
basic_examples.code:
from sklearn.cluster import KMeans
import numpy as np
X = np.array([[1,2],[1,4],[1,0],[10,2],[10,4],[10,0]])
kmeans = KMeans(n_clusters=2, random_state=0).fit(X)
print(kmeans.labels_)
basic_examples.explanation: Performs K-Means clustering on a small dataset and prints cluster labels.

advanced_examples.title: Pipeline with preprocessing and classifier
advanced_examples.code:
from sklearn.pipeline import Pipeline
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
from sklearn.svm import SVC

pipeline = Pipeline([('scaler', StandardScaler()), ('svc', SVC())])
pipeline.fit(X_train, y_train)
print(pipeline.score(X_test, y_test))
advanced_examples.explanation: Combines preprocessing and classification into a single pipeline for clean and reproducible ML workflows.

advanced_examples.title: Cross-validation
advanced_examples.code:
from sklearn.model_selection import cross_val_score
scores = cross_val_score(model, X, y, cv=5)
print(scores)
advanced_examples.explanation: Performs 5-fold cross-validation to evaluate model performance.

advanced_examples.title: Feature selection
advanced_examples.code:
from sklearn.feature_selection import SelectKBest, f_classif
selector = SelectKBest(f_classif, k=2)
X_new = selector.fit_transform(X, y)
print(X_new[:5])
advanced_examples.explanation: Selects the two most important features from the dataset using ANOVA F-value.

best_practices: Scale or normalize features when using distance-based algorithms.
Use pipelines to combine preprocessing and modeling steps.
Split data into training, validation, and test sets to avoid overfitting.
Leverage cross-validation for robust performance evaluation.
Understand the assumptions of each algorithm before applying it.

error_handling.solution: Increase `max_iter` or scale features when fitting models like LogisticRegression.
Handle missing values using `SimpleImputer` or other preprocessing techniques.

Python.name: TensorFlow
Python.description: TensorFlow is an end-to-end open-source platform for machine learning. It allows you to build and deploy machine learning models easily, from training to inference, across multiple platforms and devices.
Python.story: TensorFlow was developed by the Google Brain team and released in 2015. It was designed to provide a comprehensive ecosystem for developing, training, and deploying machine learning models. TensorFlow supports deep learning, neural networks, and large-scale numerical computations and has become one of the most widely used ML frameworks in both industry and academia.

usage.overview: TensorFlow provides APIs for building neural networks, performing automatic differentiation, training models, and serving models for production. It supports both eager execution (imperative programming) and graph execution (declarative programming).

basic_examples.title: Simple Tensor operations
basic_examples.code:
import tensorflow as tf
x = tf.constant([[1., 2.],[3., 4.]])
y = tf.constant([[5., 6.],[7., 8.]])
print(tf.matmul(x, y))
basic_examples.explanation: Defines two constant tensors and performs matrix multiplication.

basic_examples.title: Creating a simple neural network
basic_examples.code:
from tensorflow import keras
model = keras.Sequential([
    keras.layers.Dense(10, activation='relu', input_shape=(5,)),
    keras.layers.Dense(1, activation='sigmoid')
])
model.compile(optimizer='adam', loss='binary_crossentropy')
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a simple feedforward neural network with one hidden layer using the Keras API integrated in TensorFlow.

advanced_examples.title: Training a model
advanced_examples.code:
import numpy as np
X_train = np.random.rand(100,5)
y_train = np.random.randint(0,2, size=(100,1))
model.fit(X_train, y_train, epochs=10, batch_size=8)
advanced_examples.explanation: Trains the previously defined model on synthetic data for 10 epochs with a batch size of 8.

advanced_examples.title: Saving and loading a model
advanced_examples.code:
model.save('my_model')
new_model = keras.models.load_model('my_model')
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates saving a trained model and loading it later for inference or further training.

advanced_examples.title: Using TensorFlow Datasets
advanced_examples.code:
import tensorflow_datasets as tfds
dataset = tfds.load('mnist', split='train')
for example in dataset.take(1):
    image, label = example['image'], example['label']
    print(image.shape, label)

advanced_examples.title: Custom training loop with GradientTape
advanced_examples.code:
x = tf.random.normal((10,3))
y_true = tf.random.normal((10,1))
weights = tf.Variable(tf.random.normal((3,1)))
bias = tf.Variable(tf.zeros(1))
optimizer = tf.optimizers.SGD(0.01)
for i in range(100):
    with tf.GradientTape() as tape:
        y_pred = tf.matmul(x, weights) + bias
        loss = tf.reduce_mean(tf.square(y_true - y_pred))
    grads = tape.gradient(loss, [weights, bias])
    optimizer.apply_gradients(zip(grads, [weights, bias]))
advanced_examples.explanation: Implements a custom training loop to optimize weights using TensorFlow’s GradientTape and optimizer API.

Python.description: PyTorch is an open-source deep learning framework for Python that provides dynamic computation graphs, GPU acceleration, and a flexible platform for building neural networks and machine learning models.
Python.story: PyTorch was developed by Facebook's AI Research lab (FAIR) and released in 2016. It was designed to provide a more intuitive and flexible framework than TensorFlow at the time, supporting dynamic computation graphs that make debugging and experimentation easier. PyTorch quickly became popular in both research and production environments.

usage.overview: PyTorch provides tensors, autograd for automatic differentiation, neural network modules (torch.nn), optimizers, and utilities for loading and preprocessing data. It supports CPU and GPU computations seamlessly.

basic_examples.title: Creating tensors

advanced_examples.title: Defining a simple neural network
advanced_examples.code:
import torch.nn as nn
import torch.nn.functional as F

class Net(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(Net, self).__init__()
        self.fc1 = nn.Linear(10, 5)
        self.fc2 = nn.Linear(5, 1)

    def forward(self, x):
        x = F.relu(self.fc1(x))
        x = torch.sigmoid(self.fc2(x))
        return x

model = Net()
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a feedforward neural network with one hidden layer using PyTorch's nn.Module.

advanced_examples.title: Training loop example
advanced_examples.code:
import torch.optim as optim
x = torch.rand(100,10)
y = torch.rand(100,1)
criterion = nn.MSELoss()
optimizer = optim.SGD(model.parameters(), lr=0.01)

for epoch in range(10):
    optimizer.zero_grad()
    outputs = model(x)
    loss = criterion(outputs, y)
    loss.backward()
    optimizer.step()
    print(f'Epoch {epoch+1}, Loss: {loss.item()}')
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates a basic training loop for a regression model using MSE loss and SGD optimizer.

advanced_examples.title: Using GPU (CUDA)
advanced_examples.code:
device = torch.device('cuda' if torch.cuda.is_available() else 'cpu')
model.to(device)
x, y = x.to(device), y.to(device)
outputs = model(x)
advanced_examples.explanation: Moves the model and tensors to GPU for accelerated computation if available.

advanced_examples.title: Automatic differentiation
advanced_examples.code:

y = x.pow(2).sum()
y.backward()
print(x.grad)
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses autograd to automatically compute gradients of `y` with respect to `x`.

Leverage `torch.utils.data.DataLoader` for batching and shuffling datasets.

Move tensors to GPU using `.to(device)` for faster training.
Use PyTorch Lightning or similar frameworks for cleaner training loops in production.

error_handling.solution: Reduce batch size or move computations to CPU if GPU memory is insufficient.
Ensure the input and target tensors have compatible shapes for the model and loss function.
Install PyTorch using pip or conda in the current Python environment.

Python.name: Keras
Python.description: Keras is a high-level neural networks API, written in Python and capable of running on top of TensorFlow, Microsoft Cognitive Toolkit (CNTK), or Theano. It allows for easy and fast prototyping of deep learning models with minimal code.
Python.story: Keras was developed by François Chollet and released in March 2015. Its design philosophy focuses on user-friendliness, modularity, and extensibility. Keras became popular for its simple API that abstracts the complexities of deep learning, and it was later integrated tightly with TensorFlow as its official high-level API.

usage.overview: Keras allows you to define deep learning models using Sequential or Functional APIs. You can build layers, compile models, train with fit(), evaluate, and make predictions easily. It supports a wide variety of layers, optimizers, loss functions, and metrics.

basic_examples.title: Simple Sequential Model
basic_examples.code:
from tensorflow import keras
from tensorflow.keras import layers

    layers.Dense(32, activation='relu', input_shape=(784,)),
    layers.Dense(10, activation='softmax')
])
model.compile(optimizer='adam', loss='sparse_categorical_crossentropy', metrics=['accuracy'])

basic_examples.title: Training a model
basic_examples.code:
import numpy as np
X_train = np.random.rand(100,784)
y_train = np.random.randint(0,10,100)
model.fit(X_train, y_train, epochs=5, batch_size=10)

advanced_examples.title: Functional API Example
advanced_examples.code:
from tensorflow.keras import Input, Model
inputs = Input(shape=(784,))
x = layers.Dense(64, activation='relu')(inputs)
outputs = layers.Dense(10, activation='softmax')(x)
model = Model(inputs=inputs, outputs=outputs)
model.compile(optimizer='adam', loss='sparse_categorical_crossentropy', metrics=['accuracy'])
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a model using the Functional API, allowing for more flexible architectures than Sequential.

advanced_examples.title: Using Callbacks
advanced_examples.code:

advanced_examples.title: Saving and loading models
advanced_examples.code:
model.save('my_keras_model.h5')
new_model = keras.models.load_model('my_keras_model.h5')
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows how to save a trained Keras model to disk and load it later.

best_practices: Normalize input data for faster convergence.
Use validation sets and callbacks to prevent overfitting.
Leverage the Functional API for complex models like multi-input/multi-output networks.
Use pretrained models from Keras Applications for transfer learning.
Monitor training with TensorBoard for visual insights.

Check that the input shape matches the model's expected input.

Python.name: SQLAlchemy
Python.description: SQLAlchemy is a Python SQL toolkit and Object-Relational Mapping (ORM) library that gives developers full power and flexibility of SQL along with a high-level, Pythonic interface to relational databases.
Python.story: SQLAlchemy was created by Mike Bayer in 2005 to provide a powerful and flexible way to interact with relational databases in Python. It allows developers to use both raw SQL and ORM abstractions, making it suitable for both small projects and large-scale enterprise applications.

usage.overview: SQLAlchemy allows you to define database schemas as Python classes (ORM), execute raw SQL queries, and manage connections. It supports multiple relational databases such as SQLite, PostgreSQL, MySQL, and Oracle.

basic_examples.title: Creating an Engine and connecting to a database

basic_examples.title: Defining a table using ORM
