# Use detected face rectangles to compute 128D embeddings
advanced_examples.explanation: Computes 128-dimensional embeddings for detected faces for recognition tasks.

best_practices: Use dlib’s pre-trained models for face detection and recognition for accuracy and efficiency.
Convert images to RGB if they are loaded in a different color space to avoid detection errors.
Leverage GPU acceleration when training custom models for faster performance.
Use HOG-based detection for faster CPU-based inference and CNN detectors for higher accuracy.
Always handle exceptions for file paths and model loading.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the image or model file path is correct and the file exists.
Install dlib using pip or conda in your current Python environment.
Check that the image file is not corrupted and loaded correctly using skimage or OpenCV.

Python.name: Loguru
Python.description: Loguru is a Python library that simplifies logging by providing an easy-to-use, flexible, and powerful logging system. It reduces boilerplate code and adds features like sink management, message formatting, and exception catching.
Python.story: Loguru was created by Delgan in 2017 to offer a simpler, more intuitive logging experience than Python's built-in `logging` module. It aims to streamline logging setup and usage while providing advanced capabilities such as structured logging, colored outputs, and file rotation.

usage.overview: Loguru allows you to log messages with various severity levels, format logs with colors, redirect logs to files, and catch exceptions automatically. It supports both synchronous and asynchronous applications and can be easily integrated into existing projects.

basic_examples.title: Simple logging
basic_examples.code:
from loguru import logger

logger.info('This is an info message')
logger.warning('This is a warning')
basic_examples.explanation: Logs messages at different severity levels (info, warning) with minimal setup.

basic_examples.title: Logging to a file
basic_examples.code:
from loguru import logger

logger.add('file.log')
logger.info('This message is saved to a file')
basic_examples.explanation: Redirects log output to a file, creating it automatically if it doesn’t exist.

advanced_examples.title: Custom formatting
advanced_examples.code:
from loguru import logger

logger.add('file.log', format='{time} | {level} | {message}', level='INFO')
logger.info('Custom formatted log')
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses a custom log format including time, severity level, and message.

advanced_examples.title: Rotating log files
advanced_examples.code:
from loguru import logger

logger.add('file_{time}.log', rotation='1 MB')
logger.info('This log will rotate after reaching 1 MB')
advanced_examples.explanation: Automatically rotates log files when they reach a specified size.

advanced_examples.title: Catching exceptions
advanced_examples.explanation: Automatically catches exceptions in functions, logs stack traces, and prevents application crash.

advanced_examples.title: Multiple sinks
advanced_examples.code:
from loguru import logger

logger.add('file.log')
logger.add(sys.stderr, colorize=True, format='<green>{time}</green> | {level} | {message>')
logger.info('Logged to both file and console')
advanced_examples.explanation: Logs messages to multiple outputs (file and console) with independent formatting.

best_practices: Use `logger.add()` to manage multiple log destinations and formats.
Use `@logger.catch` to simplify exception handling and logging.
Set appropriate log levels for different environments (DEBUG for development, WARNING/ERROR for production).
Rotate and compress log files to prevent storage issues.
Avoid excessive logging in performance-critical code sections.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the specified log file path exists or use a valid path.
Check file permissions and ensure the application can write to the log file.

Python.name: Python Fire
Python.description: Python Fire is a library for automatically generating command-line interfaces (CLIs) from any Python object, such as functions, classes, or dictionaries. It enables rapid CLI creation without boilerplate code.
Python.story: Python Fire was created by Google in 2017 to make it easy to turn existing Python code into CLI tools. It allows developers to quickly expose functionality without writing repetitive argument parsing code, making it popular for scripting, automation, and testing.

usage.overview: Python Fire generates a CLI automatically from Python code. It parses command-line arguments and maps them to function parameters, class methods, or dictionary keys. It supports nested objects and provides help and error messages automatically.

basic_examples.title: Creating a CLI from a function
basic_examples.explanation: Generates a command-line interface where you can run `python script.py --name Alice` to print `Hello, Alice!`.

basic_examples.title: Creating a CLI from a class
basic_examples.explanation: Generates a CLI from the `Calculator` class. You can run `python script.py add 3 5` to get `8`.

advanced_examples.title: Nested commands
advanced_examples.explanation: Supports nested objects. You can run `python script.py Operations multiply 3 4` to get `12`.

advanced_examples.title: Using dictionaries
advanced_examples.explanation: Exposes a dictionary as a CLI. Running `python script.py host` prints `localhost`.

advanced_examples.title: Customizing CLI behavior
advanced_examples.explanation: Supports flags and optional arguments. Running `python script.py run --debug True` enables debug mode.

best_practices: Use Python Fire for quick CLI tools without manually parsing arguments.
Avoid exposing sensitive functions or credentials via Fire CLIs.
Keep CLI entry points simple and delegate complex logic to underlying functions or classes.
Use docstrings to provide helpful documentation for automatically generated CLI help.
Combine Fire with logging or exception handling for robust command-line tools.

error_handling.solution: Ensure that all required function parameters are provided in the CLI call.
Python Fire may not handle certain types; convert objects to standard Python types (str, int, float, list, dict) before exposing.

Python.name: Invoke
Python.description: Invoke is a Python task execution library that provides a clean, high-level API for defining and running shell-oriented tasks from Python scripts. It is designed to help automate repetitive workflows, build processes, and command-line operations.
Python.story: Invoke was created by the same team behind Fabric to provide a standalone Pythonic task execution tool. It simplifies running and organizing shell commands, tasks, and workflows in a maintainable way, allowing developers to automate build systems, deployment scripts, and other routine tasks.

usage.overview: Invoke allows you to define tasks as Python functions and execute them via the command line. Tasks can accept arguments, run shell commands, and be organized hierarchically. It provides features like namespaces, command-line parsing, and pre/post task hooks.

basic_examples.title: Defining a simple task
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a simple task named `hello`. Tasks are decorated with `@task` and receive a context `c` for running commands.

basic_examples.title: Running a task from the CLI
basic_examples.code:
# Terminal command:
# inv hello
basic_examples.explanation: Executes the `hello` task defined in `tasks.py` using the `inv` command-line tool.

advanced_examples.title: Task with arguments
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a task that accepts an argument `name`. You can call it with `inv greet --name=Alice`.

advanced_examples.title: Running shell commands
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses the context `c` to run shell commands directly from a task.

advanced_examples.title: Task namespaces
advanced_examples.explanation: Organizes tasks into namespaces for better project structure and management.

advanced_examples.title: Pre/post task hooks
advanced_examples.explanation: Executes a `setup` task automatically before running the `build` task.

best_practices: Keep tasks small and modular for clarity and maintainability.
Use namespaces to group related tasks together.
Use context (`c`) to run shell commands instead of using `os.system`.
Document tasks with docstrings so that `inv --list` provides helpful descriptions.
Combine with version control and CI/CD pipelines to automate build and deployment workflows.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when a shell command executed via `c.run()` exits with a non-zero status. Handle by using `warn=True` or try/except.
Ensure `from invoke import task` is included at the top of your tasks file.
Make sure the tasks are defined in a `tasks.py` file or properly added to a namespace and the `inv` command is run in the correct directory.

Python.name: PyInquirer
Python.description: PyInquirer is a Python library that enables the creation of beautiful, interactive command-line interfaces with prompts, lists, checkboxes, and other input types inspired by Inquirer.js.
Python.story: PyInquirer was created as a Python adaptation of the popular Inquirer.js library for Node.js. It allows developers to easily build interactive CLIs, making terminal-based tools more user-friendly and visually appealing.

usage.overview: PyInquirer provides different types of prompts such as input, confirm, list, checkbox, password, and rawlist. It supports nested questions, validation, and default values, enabling interactive CLI experiences.

basic_examples.title: Simple input prompt
basic_examples.code:
from PyInquirer import prompt

questions = [{
    'type': 'input',
    'name': 'username',
    'message': 'Enter your username:'
}]
answers = prompt(questions)
print(answers['username'])
basic_examples.explanation: Prompts the user to enter a username and prints the input.

basic_examples.title: Confirm prompt
basic_examples.code:
from PyInquirer import prompt

questions = [{
    'type': 'confirm',
    'name': 'continue',
    'message': 'Do you want to continue?',
    'default': True
}]
answers = prompt(questions)
print(answers['continue'])
basic_examples.explanation: Asks a yes/no question and returns True or False.

advanced_examples.title: List selection
advanced_examples.code:
from PyInquirer import prompt

    'type': 'list',

    'message': 'Pick a color:',

}]

advanced_examples.explanation: Displays a list of options and lets the user select one.

advanced_examples.title: Checkbox selection
advanced_examples.explanation: Allows multiple selections from a list using checkboxes.

advanced_examples.title: Validation example
advanced_examples.code:
from PyInquirer import prompt

questions = [{
    'type': 'input',
    'name': 'age',

advanced_examples.title: Nested questions
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows multiple questions sequentially and collects responses in a dictionary.

best_practices: Use descriptive messages for prompts to improve user experience.
Validate inputs to avoid invalid data.
Group related questions for clarity.
Use defaults when appropriate to simplify the workflow.
Keep the interface simple and intuitive for command-line users.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when input stream is closed unexpectedly. Ensure the terminal is interactive and supports input.
Handle user interruption gracefully by wrapping prompts in try/except blocks.

Python.name: Mechanize
Python.description: Mechanize is a Python library for stateful programmatic web browsing. It allows you to automate interaction with websites, including filling forms, clicking links, and handling cookies and sessions, similar to a web browser.
Python.story: Mechanize was created as a Python port of Perl’s Mechanize module, enabling automated browsing and web scraping in Python. It is particularly useful for automating repetitive web tasks or interacting with websites that require form submissions.

usage.overview: Mechanize provides a browser-like interface in Python. You can navigate pages, select forms, fill them out, submit them, and retrieve responses. It supports handling cookies, redirects, and headers automatically.

basic_examples.title: Opening a webpage
basic_examples.code:

br = mechanize.Browser()
br.open('http://example.com')
print(br.title())

basic_examples.title: Following a link
basic_examples.code:
link = br.find_link(text='More information')
br.follow_link(link)
print(br.geturl())

advanced_examples.title: Filling and submitting a form
advanced_examples.code:
br.select_form(nr=0)

br.submit()

advanced_examples.title: Handling cookies
advanced_examples.code:
br.set_cookiejar(mechanize.CookieJar())
br.open('http://example.com')
advanced_examples.explanation: Enables cookie handling to maintain sessions across multiple requests.

advanced_examples.title: Setting headers
advanced_examples.code:
br.addheaders = [('User-agent', 'Mozilla/5.0')]
br.open('http://example.com')
advanced_examples.explanation: Adds a custom User-Agent header to mimic a real browser.

advanced_examples.title: Handling redirects
advanced_examples.code:
br.set_handle_redirect(True)
br.open('http://example.com')
advanced_examples.explanation: Ensures the browser automatically follows HTTP redirects.

best_practices: Always set a User-Agent to avoid being blocked by websites.
Use CookieJar to manage sessions when scraping multiple pages.
Avoid scraping websites without permission; respect robots.txt.
Use proper exception handling for HTTP errors and timeouts.
Combine Mechanize with BeautifulSoup for parsing page content efficiently.

error_handling.solution: Check the response status code and ensure the URL is correct.
Verify network connectivity and the validity of the URL.
Ensure the link text exists on the page or use different selection criteria.

Python.name: Playwright-Python
Python.description: Playwright-Python is a Python library for automating web browsers. It enables end-to-end testing, web scraping, and browser automation across Chromium, Firefox, and WebKit with a single API.
Python.story: Playwright was developed by Microsoft to provide a reliable and fast automation library for testing modern web applications. The Python bindings allow developers to use Playwright's cross-browser capabilities, including headless and headful modes, to automate interactions with web pages.

usage.overview: Playwright allows you to launch browsers, navigate pages, interact with elements, capture screenshots, and evaluate JavaScript code. It supports synchronous and asynchronous APIs and provides robust mechanisms for waiting, network interception, and handling popups or frames.

basic_examples.title: Opening a page and taking a screenshot
basic_examples.code:
from playwright.sync_api import sync_playwright

    browser = p.chromium.launch(headless=True)
    page = browser.new_page()
    page.goto('https://example.com')
    page.screenshot(path='example.png')
    browser.close()
basic_examples.explanation: Launches a Chromium browser in headless mode, navigates to a URL, takes a screenshot, and closes the browser.

basic_examples.title: Clicking a button
basic_examples.code:
from playwright.sync_api import sync_playwright

with sync_playwright() as p:
    browser = p.chromium.launch()
    page = browser.new_page()
    page.goto('https://example.com')
    page.click('text=More information')
    browser.close()
basic_examples.explanation: Navigates to a page and clicks a button or link with the text 'More information'.

advanced_examples.title: Filling a form and submitting
advanced_examples.code:
from playwright.sync_api import sync_playwright

with sync_playwright() as p:
    browser = p.chromium.launch()
    page = browser.new_page()

advanced_examples.title: Handling popups
advanced_examples.code:

page.click('#open-popup')

advanced_examples.title: Extracting page content
advanced_examples.code:
content = page.inner_text('#main')
print(content)
advanced_examples.explanation: Extracts the text content of a specific element on the page.

best_practices: Use synchronous API for simple scripts and asynchronous API for large-scale automation.
Prefer headless mode for faster execution unless debugging.
Leverage selectors efficiently to avoid brittle scripts.
Wait explicitly for elements or network events to ensure reliability.
Organize automation scripts into reusable functions or classes for maintainability.

error_handling.solution: Increase the timeout or ensure the element is correctly targeted and visible before interaction.

error_handling.error: PlaywrightError: No node found for selector
error_handling.solution: Verify the selector is correct and matches an element on the page.
Ensure the browser binaries are installed with `playwright install` and the environment supports GUI if headless=False.

Python.name: Selenium
Python.description: Selenium is a powerful Python library for automating web browsers. It allows you to programmatically interact with web pages, simulate user actions, and perform browser testing across multiple browsers.
Python.story: Selenium was originally developed in 2004 by Jason Huggins at ThoughtWorks as an internal tool for automated testing of web applications. Over time, it evolved into a widely-used framework for browser automation, supporting multiple programming languages and browser drivers. Selenium WebDriver became the standard API for reliable cross-browser automation.

usage.overview: Selenium allows you to control browsers using WebDriver. You can navigate pages, click buttons, fill forms, extract text, take screenshots, handle alerts, and perform automated testing. It supports Chrome, Firefox, Edge, Safari, and other major browsers.

basic_examples.title: Opening a webpage
basic_examples.code:

driver = webdriver.Chrome()
driver.get('https://example.com')
print(driver.title)
driver.quit()
basic_examples.explanation: Launches Chrome, navigates to the URL, prints the page title, and closes the browser.

basic_examples.title: Finding elements by ID or Name
basic_examples.code:
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

driver = webdriver.Chrome()
driver.get('https://example.com')
element = driver.find_element(By.ID, 'username')
element.send_keys('myuser')
driver.quit()
basic_examples.explanation: Locates an input field using its ID and types text into it.

advanced_examples.title: Clicking a button
advanced_examples.code:
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
button = driver.find_element(By.XPATH, '//button[text()="Submit"]')
button.click()
advanced_examples.explanation: Finds a button by XPath and simulates a click.

advanced_examples.title: Waiting for elements
advanced_examples.code:
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait
from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC

wait = WebDriverWait(driver, 10)
element = wait.until(EC.presence_of_element_located((By.ID, 'result')))
advanced_examples.explanation: Waits up to 10 seconds for an element to appear before proceeding.

advanced_examples.title: Handling alerts
advanced_examples.code:
alert = driver.switch_to.alert
alert.accept()
advanced_examples.explanation: Switches to a JavaScript alert and accepts it.

advanced_examples.title: Taking screenshots
advanced_examples.code: driver.save_screenshot('screenshot.png')
advanced_examples.explanation: Saves a screenshot of the current browser window.

advanced_examples.title: Headless mode
advanced_examples.code:
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
options = Options()
options.headless = True
driver = webdriver.Chrome(options=options)
advanced_examples.explanation: Runs Chrome in headless mode for faster automation without opening a visible window.

best_practices: Use explicit waits (`WebDriverWait`) instead of arbitrary sleep times for stability.
Close or quit browser instances to free resources.
Use headless mode for automation scripts that don't require UI interaction.
Leverage browser-specific options and capabilities for optimized performance.
Keep WebDriver versions compatible with the browser version installed.

error_handling.solution: Verify the selector used to locate the element and ensure it exists on the page.

error_handling.error: WebDriverException: Message: 'chromedriver' executable needs to be in PATH
error_handling.solution: Download the correct WebDriver for your browser and ensure it is in your system PATH.
Increase the wait time or check that the expected condition is correct.

Python.name: Requests-HTML
Python.description: Requests-HTML is a Python library that combines the simplicity of the Requests library with powerful HTML parsing, web scraping, and asynchronous capabilities. It allows developers to easily fetch, parse, and manipulate HTML content.
Python.story: Requests-HTML was created by Kenneth Reitz as an extension to the popular Requests library. Its goal was to simplify web scraping and HTML parsing in Python by providing a high-level, Pythonic API. It supports JavaScript rendering using Pyppeteer, making it suitable for modern websites with dynamic content.

usage.overview: Requests-HTML allows sending HTTP requests, parsing HTML content, executing JavaScript, and extracting data using CSS selectors or XPath. It provides synchronous and asynchronous APIs for web scraping and automation tasks.

basic_examples.title: Fetching a webpage
basic_examples.code:
from requests_html import HTMLSession
session = HTMLSession()
response = session.get('https://example.com')
print(response.html.title)
basic_examples.explanation: Creates an HTML session, fetches a webpage, and prints the page title.

basic_examples.title: Finding elements with CSS selectors
basic_examples.explanation: Uses CSS selectors to find all anchor tags and prints their text and href attributes.

advanced_examples.title: Rendering JavaScript
advanced_examples.code:
r = session.get('https://example.com')
r.html.render()
print(r.html.html)
advanced_examples.explanation: Renders JavaScript on the page, allowing scraping of dynamically generated content.

advanced_examples.title: Extracting data with XPath
advanced_examples.code:
titles = response.html.xpath('//h1/text()')
print(titles)
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses XPath expressions to extract the text of all `<h1>` elements.

advanced_examples.title: Using asynchronous requests
advanced_examples.code:
from requests_html import AsyncHTMLSession
asession = AsyncHTMLSession()

async def get_page():
    r = await asession.get('https://example.com')
    print(r.html.title)

asession.run(get_page)
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates asynchronous fetching of a webpage using AsyncHTMLSession.

advanced_examples.title: Handling forms
advanced_examples.explanation: Extracts a form from the page, prepares the data, and submits it via POST.

best_practices: Use `.render()` only when necessary since JavaScript rendering is resource-intensive.
Leverage CSS selectors for simple element extraction and XPath for complex queries.
Use sessions to persist cookies and headers across multiple requests.
Combine Requests-HTML with other libraries like BeautifulSoup or Pandas for processing and analysis.
Handle exceptions for network issues or rendering errors gracefully.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the session is properly created and the URL is correct.
Ensure Pyppeteer is installed and the environment supports headless browser execution.
Check network connectivity and the validity of the target URL.

Python.name: Tortoise-ORM
Python.description: Tortoise-ORM is an easy-to-use, asyncio-supporting Object-Relational Mapper (ORM) for Python, designed to provide a simple, familiar interface similar to Django ORM but fully asynchronous.
Python.story: Tortoise-ORM was created to offer a lightweight, asynchronous ORM for Python developers using async frameworks like FastAPI and Starlette. It emphasizes simplicity, performance, and developer-friendly APIs, supporting multiple database backends including SQLite, PostgreSQL, and MySQL.

usage.overview: Tortoise-ORM allows you to define models as Python classes, perform asynchronous CRUD operations, manage relationships, and use querysets similar to Django ORM. It supports migrations via Aerich and integrates seamlessly with async web frameworks.

basic_examples.title: Defining a simple model
basic_examples.code:
from tortoise import Tortoise, fields, models

class User(models.Model):
    id = fields.IntField(pk=True)
    name = fields.CharField(max_length=50)
    email = fields.CharField(max_length=100, unique=True)
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a `User` model with id, name, and unique email fields using Tortoise ORM.

basic_examples.title: Initializing the ORM and connecting to the database
basic_examples.code:
import asyncio

async def init():
    await Tortoise.init(db_url='sqlite://db.sqlite3', modules={'models': ['__main__']})
    await Tortoise.generate_schemas()

asyncio.run(init())
basic_examples.explanation: Initializes Tortoise ORM with a SQLite database and generates database tables based on the models.

advanced_examples.title: Creating a record asynchronously
advanced_examples.code:
async def create_user():
    user = await User.create(name='Alice', email='alice@example.com')
    print(user.id)

asyncio.run(create_user())
advanced_examples.explanation: Creates a new user record asynchronously and prints its auto-generated ID.

advanced_examples.title: Querying data
advanced_examples.code:
async def get_users():
    users = await User.filter(name='Alice')
    for user in users:
        print(user.name, user.email)

asyncio.run(get_users())
advanced_examples.explanation: Fetches all users with the name 'Alice' and prints their details asynchronously.

advanced_examples.title: Updating a record
advanced_examples.code:
async def update_user():
    user = await User.get(id=1)
    user.name = 'Bob'
    await user.save()

asyncio.run(update_user())
advanced_examples.explanation: Fetches a user by ID, updates the name, and saves the changes asynchronously.

advanced_examples.title: Deleting a record
advanced_examples.code:
async def delete_user():
    user = await User.get(id=1)
    await user.delete()

asyncio.run(delete_user())
advanced_examples.explanation: Fetches a user by ID and deletes it from the database asynchronously.

advanced_examples.title: Defining relationships
advanced_examples.code:
class Post(models.Model):
    id = fields.IntField(pk=True)
    title = fields.CharField(max_length=100)
    author = fields.ForeignKeyField('models.User', related_name='posts')
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a `Post` model with a foreign key relationship to the `User` model.

advanced_examples.title: Querying related objects
advanced_examples.code:
async def get_user_posts():
    user = await User.get(id=1)
    posts = await user.posts.all()
    for post in posts:
        print(post.title)

asyncio.run(get_user_posts())
advanced_examples.explanation: Fetches all posts authored by a specific user using the related name.

best_practices: Use async/await syntax consistently when interacting with the database.
Define related_name for relationships for cleaner reverse lookups.
Use Aerich for database migrations to track schema changes.
Keep models modular and organized per app/module.
Handle exceptions such as DoesNotExist and IntegrityError when performing CRUD operations.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when querying a model instance that does not exist. Use try/except or `.first()` to avoid exceptions.
Raised when unique constraints or foreign key constraints are violated. Ensure input data respects constraints.
Occurs when the database connection fails. Check DB URL, network, or migrations.

Python.name: Peewee
Python.description: Peewee is a small, expressive ORM (Object-Relational Mapping) library for Python. It provides a simple and lightweight way to interact with databases using Pythonic models and queries, supporting SQLite, MySQL, and PostgreSQL.
Python.story: Peewee was created by Charles Leifer to provide a minimalistic ORM alternative that is easy to learn and integrate into Python projects. It emphasizes simplicity and readability while still offering sufficient functionality for most database tasks, making it popular for small to medium-sized applications.

usage.overview: Peewee allows you to define models as Python classes that map to database tables. You can perform CRUD operations, define relationships, execute queries, and manage transactions with a simple and intuitive API.

basic_examples.title: Defining a model
basic_examples.code:
from peewee import Model, CharField, SqliteDatabase

db = SqliteDatabase('my_database.db')

class User(Model):
    name = CharField()
    email = CharField(unique=True)

    class Meta:
        database = db

db.connect()
db.create_tables([User])
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a `User` model with `name` and unique `email` fields, connects to a SQLite database, and creates the corresponding table.

basic_examples.title: Inserting a record
basic_examples.code: user = User.create(name='Alice', email='alice@example.com')
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a new user record and saves it to the database.

advanced_examples.title: Querying records
advanced_examples.explanation: Selects all users with the name 'Alice' and prints their details.

advanced_examples.title: Updating records
advanced_examples.code:
query = User.update(email='alice_new@example.com').where(User.name=='Alice')
query.execute()
advanced_examples.explanation: Updates the email of users with name 'Alice'.

advanced_examples.title: Deleting records
advanced_examples.code:
query = User.delete().where(User.name=='Alice')
query.execute()
advanced_examples.explanation: Deletes users with name 'Alice' from the database.

advanced_examples.title: Defining relationships
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a `Post` model with a foreign key relationship to the `User` model, allowing reverse lookups via `user.posts`.

advanced_examples.title: Transactions
advanced_examples.code:
with db.atomic():
    User.create(name='Bob', email='bob@example.com')
    User.create(name='Charlie', email='charlie@example.com')
advanced_examples.explanation: Performs multiple database operations within a transaction, ensuring atomicity.

best_practices: Use `db.atomic()` for grouping multiple operations to ensure atomicity.
Define relationships with `ForeignKeyField` and `backref` for clean data access.
Use Peewee’s built-in query methods instead of raw SQL for consistency and safety.
Keep models modular and separated per app/module for maintainability.
Close database connections after use to prevent resource leaks.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when unique constraints or foreign key constraints are violated. Ensure input data respects constraints.
Check database connectivity, schema, or syntax for errors.
Raised when a query for a specific record does not return any results. Handle with try/except blocks or use `.get_or_none()`.

Python.name: MongoEngine
Python.description: MongoEngine is an Object-Document Mapper (ODM) for Python that provides a high-level abstraction for working with MongoDB. It allows developers to define schemas and interact with MongoDB documents using Python classes instead of raw queries.
Python.story: MongoEngine was created by Michael Bayer and others to provide a Pythonic interface for MongoDB, similar to how SQLAlchemy provides an ORM for SQL databases. It is widely used in Python web applications and projects requiring flexible NoSQL data storage, offering schema validation, query building, and relationship management.

usage.overview: MongoEngine allows you to define document schemas as Python classes, perform CRUD operations, build queries, and handle embedded documents and references. It integrates well with web frameworks like Flask and Django.

basic_examples.title: Connecting to MongoDB
basic_examples.code:
from mongoengine import connect
connect('mydb')
basic_examples.explanation: Connects to a MongoDB database named 'mydb'. You can also specify host, port, username, and password.

basic_examples.title: Defining a simple document
basic_examples.code:
from mongoengine import Document, StringField, IntField

class User(Document):
    name = StringField(required=True, max_length=50)
    age = IntField()
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a `User` document with `name` and `age` fields, including basic validation.

basic_examples.title: Creating a document
basic_examples.code:
user = User(name='Alice', age=25)
user.save()
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a new `User` document and saves it to the database.

advanced_examples.title: Querying documents
advanced_examples.explanation: Fetches all users aged 18 or older using MongoEngine’s query syntax.

advanced_examples.title: Updating documents
advanced_examples.code: User.objects(name='Alice').update(set__age=26)
advanced_examples.explanation: Updates the age of users named 'Alice' to 26.

advanced_examples.title: Deleting documents
advanced_examples.code: User.objects(name='Alice').delete()
advanced_examples.explanation: Deletes all users with the name 'Alice'.

advanced_examples.title: Embedded documents
advanced_examples.code:
from mongoengine import EmbeddedDocument, EmbeddedDocumentField

class Address(EmbeddedDocument):
    street = StringField()
    city = StringField()

class User(Document):
    name = StringField()
    address = EmbeddedDocumentField(Address)
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows how to define embedded documents to represent nested structures.

advanced_examples.title: Reference fields (relationships)
advanced_examples.code:
from mongoengine import ReferenceField

class Post(Document):
    title = StringField()
    author = ReferenceField(User)
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a relationship between `Post` and `User` documents using reference fields.

best_practices: Use schema validation in your Document fields to prevent inconsistent data.
Prefer query filters over iterating all documents for efficiency.
Close the connection explicitly in long-running scripts using `disconnect()` if needed.
Use indexes for frequently queried fields to improve performance.
Leverage embedded documents for tightly coupled data and references for loosely coupled relationships.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when a document fails field validation. Check field types, required fields, and constraints.
Raised when attempting to insert a document with a value that violates a unique constraint.
Thrown when querying for a document that does not exist. Use `.first()` or handle exceptions.

Python.name: Paramiko
Python.description: Paramiko is a Python library for SSH2 protocol, providing both client and server functionality. It allows you to securely connect to remote machines, execute commands, transfer files over SFTP, and manage SSH sessions programmatically.
Python.story: Paramiko was created by Robey Pointer in 2003 to provide a pure-Python implementation of the SSHv2 protocol. It became a popular tool for automating server administration, remote command execution, and secure file transfers in Python applications.

usage.overview: Paramiko provides SSH client and server implementations. You can connect to remote servers, run shell commands, upload and download files using SFTP, and handle keys and authentication. It supports password and key-based authentication, as well as SSH agent integration.

basic_examples.title: SSH Connection and Command Execution
basic_examples.code:
import paramiko

ssh = paramiko.SSHClient()
ssh.set_missing_host_key_policy(paramiko.AutoAddPolicy())
ssh.connect('example.com', username='user', password='pass')
stdin, stdout, stderr = ssh.exec_command('ls -l')
print(stdout.read().decode())
ssh.close()
basic_examples.explanation: Connects to a remote server via SSH, executes the `ls -l` command, prints the output, and closes the connection.

basic_examples.title: Using Key-Based Authentication
basic_examples.code:
import paramiko

ssh = paramiko.SSHClient()
ssh.set_missing_host_key_policy(paramiko.AutoAddPolicy())
private_key = paramiko.RSAKey.from_private_key_file('/path/to/key.pem')
ssh.connect('example.com', username='user', pkey=private_key)
stdin, stdout, stderr = ssh.exec_command('uptime')
print(stdout.read().decode())
ssh.close()
basic_examples.explanation: Uses an RSA private key for authentication instead of a password to connect to a remote server.

advanced_examples.title: SFTP File Transfer
advanced_examples.code:
import paramiko

transport = paramiko.Transport(('example.com', 22))
transport.connect(username='user', password='pass')
sftp = paramiko.SFTPClient.from_transport(transport)
sftp.put('local_file.txt', 'remote_file.txt')
sftp.get('remote_file.txt', 'local_copy.txt')
sftp.close()
transport.close()
advanced_examples.explanation: Uploads a local file to a remote server and downloads a file back using SFTP.

advanced_examples.title: SSH with Context Manager
advanced_examples.code:
import paramiko

with paramiko.SSHClient() as ssh:
    ssh.set_missing_host_key_policy(paramiko.AutoAddPolicy())
    ssh.connect('example.com', username='user', password='pass')
    stdin, stdout, stderr = ssh.exec_command('whoami')
    print(stdout.read().decode())
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses a context manager to automatically handle SSH connection closing.

advanced_examples.title: Using SSH Agent
advanced_examples.code:
import paramiko
agent = paramiko.Agent()
keys = agent.get_keys()
ssh = paramiko.SSHClient()
ssh.set_missing_host_key_policy(paramiko.AutoAddPolicy())
ssh.connect('example.com', username='user', pkey=keys[0])
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses keys from an SSH agent for authentication.

best_practices: Always handle missing host keys with `AutoAddPolicy()` or manually add known hosts.
Prefer key-based authentication over passwords for better security.
Close SSH and SFTP connections properly to release resources.
Use paramiko logging to debug connection and authentication issues.
For long-running scripts, handle network interruptions and reconnections.

error_handling.solution: Raised when authentication fails. Verify username, password, and key files.
General SSH error. Check server status and compatibility with Paramiko.
Occurs when unable to connect to the specified host/port. Ensure the server is accessible.

Python.name: Asyncio
Python.description: Asyncio is Python's standard library for writing concurrent code using the async/await syntax. It provides an event loop, coroutines, tasks, and futures to facilitate asynchronous programming and I/O-bound operations.
Python.story: Asyncio was introduced in Python 3.4 (2014) to provide a built-in framework for asynchronous programming, inspired by frameworks like Twisted and Tornado. It enables efficient handling of I/O-bound tasks, networking, and high-performance applications without using traditional threading or multiprocessing.

usage.overview: Asyncio allows you to define coroutines with `async def`, schedule them for execution, and manage asynchronous tasks. It is ideal for network operations, file I/O, concurrency, and writing scalable applications.

basic_examples.title: Simple coroutine
basic_examples.code:
import asyncio

async def say_hello():
    print('Hello')
    await asyncio.sleep(1)
    print('World')

asyncio.run(say_hello())
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a coroutine using `async def` and runs it with `asyncio.run()`. Demonstrates non-blocking sleep.

basic_examples.title: Running multiple coroutines concurrently
basic_examples.code:
import asyncio

async def task(name, delay):
    await asyncio.sleep(delay)
    print(f'Task {name} completed')

async def main():
    await asyncio.gather(task('A', 2), task('B', 1))

asyncio.run(main())
basic_examples.explanation: Uses `asyncio.gather` to run multiple coroutines concurrently, printing output when each finishes.

advanced_examples.title: Creating tasks
advanced_examples.code:
import asyncio

async def my_task():
    await asyncio.sleep(1)
    print('Task done')

task = asyncio.create_task(my_task())
asyncio.run(task)
advanced_examples.explanation: Wraps a coroutine in a Task, allowing it to run in the background.

advanced_examples.title: Using async context managers
advanced_examples.code:
import asyncio

class AsyncResource:
    async def __aenter__(self):
        print('Enter')
        return self
    async def __aexit__(self, exc_type, exc, tb):
        print('Exit')

async def main():
    async with AsyncResource():
        print('Inside context')

asyncio.run(main())
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates the use of async context managers to manage resources asynchronously.

advanced_examples.title: Networking with asyncio
advanced_examples.code:
import asyncio

async def tcp_echo_client(message):
    reader, writer = await asyncio.open_connection('127.0.0.1', 8888)
    writer.write(message.encode())
    await writer.drain()
    data = await reader.read(100)
    print(f'Received: {data.decode()}')
    writer.close()
    await writer.wait_closed()

asyncio.run(tcp_echo_client('Hello'))
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows a simple TCP client using asyncio for asynchronous network I/O.

advanced_examples.title: Scheduling periodic tasks
advanced_examples.code:
import asyncio

async def periodic():
    while True:
        print('Tick')
        await asyncio.sleep(1)

asyncio.run(periodic())
advanced_examples.explanation: Runs a coroutine repeatedly at fixed intervals using a loop with `await asyncio.sleep()`.

best_practices: Prefer `asyncio.run()` for top-level entry points in Python 3.7+.
Use `async/await` syntax instead of `@asyncio.coroutine` for readability.
Leverage `asyncio.gather()` for running multiple coroutines concurrently.
Use Tasks for background execution and long-running operations.
Avoid blocking calls in async functions; use non-blocking I/O libraries.

error_handling.solution: Ensure you are not calling `asyncio.run()` from within an already running event loop.
Occurs when a task is cancelled. Handle with try/except around awaited tasks.
Use `asyncio.wait_for()` or `asyncio.timeout()` to limit the duration of coroutines safely.

Python.name: Twisted
Python.description: Twisted is an event-driven networking engine written in Python. It provides a robust framework for building asynchronous networked applications, including servers, clients, and protocols for TCP, UDP, SSL/TLS, and more.
Python.story: Twisted was created by Glyph Lefkowitz in 2002 to simplify the development of networked applications in Python. It focuses on asynchronous I/O, making it suitable for high-performance network servers and clients. Twisted supports multiple protocols out-of-the-box and has a flexible architecture for custom protocol implementation.

usage.overview: Twisted uses an event-driven programming model where the reactor loop manages asynchronous events. Developers define protocols and factories to handle network events, such as connections, data received, and errors.

basic_examples.title: Simple TCP server
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a TCP server on port 8000 that echoes back any data received.

basic_examples.title: Simple TCP client
basic_examples.explanation: Connects to a TCP server, sends a message, prints the response, and closes the connection.

advanced_examples.title: Using Deferreds
advanced_examples.code:
from twisted.internet import reactor, defer

def got_result(result):
    print('Result:', result)
    reactor.stop()

d = defer.Deferred()
d.addCallback(got_result)
d.callback('Hello Twisted')
reactor.run()
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates the use of Deferred objects for handling asynchronous results and callbacks.

advanced_examples.title: HTTP client request
advanced_examples.code:
from twisted.web.client import getPage
from twisted.internet import reactor

def print_result(result):
    print(result)
    reactor.stop()

getPage(b'http://httpbin.org/get').addCallback(print_result)
reactor.run()
advanced_examples.explanation: Performs an asynchronous HTTP GET request and prints the page content.

advanced_examples.title: Using SSL/TLS
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows how to establish a secure SSL/TLS client connection using Twisted.

best_practices: Use the reactor loop for all asynchronous operations.
Leverage Deferreds for handling asynchronous callbacks and chaining operations.
Use Factories to manage protocol instances and connections.
Avoid blocking calls inside Twisted protocols; use threads or deferToThread for blocking operations.
Use Twisted’s built-in protocols and utilities to simplify network programming.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the server is running and reachable at the specified host and port.
Check that reactor.run() has been called and not stopped prematurely.
Use Twisted’s timeout mechanisms or Deferred timeouts to handle slow connections.

Python.name: Pathlib
Python.description: Pathlib is a Python standard library module that provides an object-oriented interface for working with filesystem paths. It simplifies file and directory manipulations across different operating systems.
Python.story: Pathlib was introduced in Python 3.4 to offer a more intuitive, object-oriented approach to handling filesystem paths compared to the traditional `os.path` module. It unifies the handling of files and directories, making code cleaner, more readable, and portable.

usage.overview: Pathlib allows you to create, manipulate, and query file paths using Path objects. It supports operations like checking existence, reading/writing files, creating directories, iterating over directories, and handling path joins in a platform-independent way.

basic_examples.title: Creating a Path object
basic_examples.code:
from pathlib import Path
path = Path('/home/user/docs')
print(path.exists())
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a Path object pointing to a directory and checks whether it exists.

basic_examples.title: Joining paths
basic_examples.code:
from pathlib import Path
path = Path('/home/user') / 'docs' / 'file.txt'
print(path)
basic_examples.explanation: Joins path components using the `/` operator in a platform-independent way.

basic_examples.title: Iterating over files in a directory
basic_examples.code:
from pathlib import Path
path = Path('/home/user/docs')
for file in path.iterdir():
    print(file.name)
basic_examples.explanation: Iterates over all files and directories inside the given path.

advanced_examples.title: Reading and writing files
advanced_examples.code:
from pathlib import Path
path = Path('example.txt')
path.write_text('Hello, Pathlib!')
content = path.read_text()
print(content)
advanced_examples.explanation: Writes text to a file and then reads it back using Path methods.

advanced_examples.title: Creating directories
advanced_examples.code:
from pathlib import Path
path = Path('new_folder')
path.mkdir(exist_ok=True)
advanced_examples.explanation: Creates a new directory. The `exist_ok=True` argument prevents errors if the directory already exists.

advanced_examples.title: Checking file properties
advanced_examples.code:
from pathlib import Path
path = Path('example.txt')
print(path.is_file())
print(path.is_dir())
print(path.suffix)
advanced_examples.explanation: Checks if the path is a file or directory and prints the file extension.

advanced_examples.title: Glob pattern matching
advanced_examples.code:
from pathlib import Path
path = Path('/home/user/docs')
for txt_file in path.glob('*.txt'):
    print(txt_file)
advanced_examples.explanation: Finds all `.txt` files in the specified directory using glob patterns.

advanced_examples.title: Recursive globbing
advanced_examples.code:
from pathlib import Path
path = Path('/home/user/docs')
for py_file in path.rglob('*.py'):
    print(py_file)
advanced_examples.explanation: Recursively searches for all `.py` files in the directory and its subdirectories.

best_practices: Prefer Path objects over string paths for cleaner and safer code.
Use `/` operator to join paths instead of `os.path.join()` for readability.

Python.name: Pendulum
Python.description: Pendulum is a Python library for handling dates, times, and time zones. It provides a cleaner and more intuitive API than the standard `datetime` module, with precise parsing, formatting, and manipulation of date and time objects.
Python.story: Pendulum was created by Sébastien Règne to address the limitations and complexities of Python’s built-in `datetime` module. It focuses on simplicity, correctness, and timezone awareness, making it suitable for applications where robust date and time handling is critical.

usage.overview: Pendulum allows creating and manipulating dates and times, handling time zones, formatting, parsing strings, and performing arithmetic with durations. It is fully compatible with Python's `datetime` module but offers additional convenience methods and immutability.

Python.name: PyYAML

from telegram import Update

    update.message.reply_text('Hello! I am your bot.')

updater = Updater(TOKEN)
updater.dispatcher.add_handler(CommandHandler('start', start))
updater.start_polling()
updater.idle()

advanced_examples.title: Using inline keyboards
advanced_examples.code:
from telegram import InlineKeyboardButton, InlineKeyboardMarkup
from telegram.ext import Updater, CommandHandler, CallbackQueryHandler

TOKEN = 'YOUR_BOT_TOKEN'

def start(update, context):
    keyboard = [[InlineKeyboardButton('Option 1', callback_data='1'),
                 InlineKeyboardButton('Option 2', callback_data='2')]]
    reply_markup = InlineKeyboardMarkup(keyboard)
    update.message.reply_text('Choose:', reply_markup=reply_markup)

def button(update, context):
    query = update.callback_query
    query.answer()
    query.edit_message_text(text=f'Selected option: {query.data}')

updater = Updater(TOKEN)
updater.dispatcher.add_handler(CommandHandler('start', start))
updater.dispatcher.add_handler(CallbackQueryHandler(button))
updater.start_polling()
updater.idle()
advanced_examples.explanation: Creates a bot with an inline keyboard, and edits the message based on the user selection.

async def start(update: Update, context):

app.add_handler(CommandHandler('start', start))
asyncio.run(app.run_polling())
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates creating an asynchronous bot using the latest ApplicationBuilder and asyncio support.

Use logging to monitor bot activity and errors.

advanced_examples.explanation: Uses Hibernate Query Language (HQL) to fetch users with a specific name.

advanced_examples.title: Updating an entity
