advanced_examples.title: Deleting an entity
advanced_examples.explanation: Deletes a user entity from the database.

best_practices: Use JPA annotations for entity mapping for portability.
Always manage transactions explicitly for consistency.
Close sessions to release database connections.
Use caching (first-level and second-level) to improve performance.
Prefer parameterized queries or HQL to prevent SQL injection.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when accessing uninitialized lazy-loaded associations outside of session. Ensure session is open or fetch eagerly.
General Hibernate exception. Check configuration, mappings, and session handling.
Occurs when database constraints (e.g., unique, not null) are violated. Validate data before saving.

Java.name: Jackson
Java.description: Jackson is a high-performance JSON processor for Java. It allows for parsing, generating, and transforming JSON data, and integrates seamlessly with Java objects using annotations and data binding.
Java.story: Jackson was created to provide a flexible, efficient, and feature-rich library for working with JSON in Java. It supports streaming, tree model, and data-binding approaches, making it popular for REST APIs, configuration parsing, and data serialization.

usage.overview: Jackson allows Java developers to serialize Java objects to JSON and deserialize JSON into Java objects. It supports annotations for customizing serialization, ignores unknown properties, and integrates with frameworks like Spring Boot.

basic_examples.title: Serializing a Java object to JSON
basic_examples.explanation: Converts a Java object `User` into a JSON string using `ObjectMapper`.

basic_examples.title: Deserializing JSON to a Java object
basic_examples.explanation: Converts a JSON string into a Java `User` object using Jackson.

advanced_examples.title: Ignoring unknown properties
advanced_examples.explanation: Prevents Jackson from failing when extra fields exist in JSON that are not in the Java class.

advanced_examples.title: Custom serialization
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates customizing how a Java object is serialized to JSON.

advanced_examples.title: Working with Collections
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows serialization and deserialization of lists of Java objects.

advanced_examples.title: Tree model for dynamic JSON
advanced_examples.code:
JsonNode rootNode = mapper.readTree(json);
String name = rootNode.get("name").asText();
advanced_examples.explanation: Allows parsing JSON into a tree structure for dynamic access without mapping to a Java class.

best_practices: Use `ObjectMapper` as a singleton to avoid performance overhead.
Leverage annotations like `@JsonProperty`, `@JsonIgnore`, and `@JsonInclude` for fine-grained control.
Handle unknown properties gracefully with `@JsonIgnoreProperties`.
Use TypeReference for deserializing generic types like lists and maps.
Integrate with Spring Boot’s `MappingJackson2HttpMessageConverter` for REST APIs.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when JSON cannot be mapped to Java object. Ensure field names and types match.
Occurs when JSON is invalid or malformed. Validate JSON input before deserialization.
Occurs during I/O operations. Handle file/stream errors when reading or writing JSON.

Java.name: Gson
Java.description: Gson is a Java library by Google for converting Java objects to JSON and vice versa. It supports serialization and deserialization of Java objects, including collections, generics, and nested objects.
Java.story: Gson was created by Google to provide a simple and efficient way to handle JSON in Java applications. It emphasizes ease-of-use, flexibility, and compatibility with standard Java types, making it popular for REST APIs and configuration handling.

usage.overview: Gson allows developers to serialize Java objects into JSON strings and deserialize JSON strings into Java objects. It supports custom serializers, deserializers, and works well with collections and complex object hierarchies.

basic_examples.title: Serializing a Java object to JSON
basic_examples.explanation: Converts a Java object `User` into a JSON string using Gson.

basic_examples.title: Deserializing JSON to a Java object
basic_examples.explanation: Converts a JSON string into a Java `User` object using Gson.

advanced_examples.title: Working with Lists
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates serialization and deserialization of lists of Java objects using `TypeToken`.

advanced_examples.title: Custom serialization
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows how to customize serialization by implementing `JsonSerializer`.

advanced_examples.title: Excluding fields with @Expose
advanced_examples.explanation: Only fields annotated with `@Expose` will be serialized when using `GsonBuilder().excludeFieldsWithoutExposeAnnotation()`.

advanced_examples.title: Pretty printing JSON
advanced_examples.explanation: Formats JSON output for readability.

best_practices: Use `Gson` as a singleton to improve performance.
Use `TypeToken` when deserializing generic types like collections.
Leverage `@Expose` and `GsonBuilder` for field-level control.
Handle null values explicitly with `serializeNulls()` if needed.
Prefer Gson for simple JSON processing; use Jackson for complex or high-performance scenarios.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when the JSON is malformed or doesn't match the Java object structure. Validate JSON input.
Occurs during I/O operations. Handle stream/file errors when reading or writing JSON.
Occurs when parsing fails. Ensure JSON format is correct and compatible with the target class.

Java.name: OkHttp
Java.description: OkHttp is a modern, efficient, and feature-rich HTTP client for Java and Android. It supports HTTP/1.1, HTTP/2, WebSocket, connection pooling, and transparent GZIP compression.
Java.story: OkHttp was created by Square to provide a reliable and performant HTTP client for Java applications. It handles connection management, retries, caching, and asynchronous requests efficiently, making it popular for REST API clients.

usage.overview: OkHttp allows developers to send synchronous and asynchronous HTTP requests, manage headers and cookies, handle redirects, and stream responses. It integrates seamlessly with JSON libraries like Gson or Jackson.

basic_examples.title: Simple GET request
basic_examples.explanation: Sends a synchronous GET request to a URL and prints the response body.

basic_examples.title: Simple POST request with JSON
basic_examples.explanation: Sends a POST request with a JSON payload.

advanced_examples.title: Asynchronous request
advanced_examples.explanation: Executes an HTTP request asynchronously using a callback.

advanced_examples.title: Adding headers
advanced_examples.code:
Request request = new Request.Builder()
    .url("https://api.example.com")
    .addHeader("Authorization", "Bearer TOKEN")
    .build();
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates adding custom HTTP headers to a request.

advanced_examples.title: Connection pooling and timeouts
advanced_examples.code:
OkHttpClient client = new OkHttpClient.Builder()
    .connectTimeout(10, TimeUnit.SECONDS)
    .readTimeout(30, TimeUnit.SECONDS)
    .build();
advanced_examples.explanation: Configures OkHttp client with custom timeouts for connection and reading.

advanced_examples.title: Using interceptors
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses an interceptor to modify requests globally.

best_practices: Reuse `OkHttpClient` instances to leverage connection pooling.
Use asynchronous calls for network operations to avoid blocking the main thread.
Use interceptors for logging, authentication, or request/response modification.
Handle network exceptions gracefully and implement retries if necessary.
Integrate with JSON libraries like Gson or Jackson for payload serialization/deserialization.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when network request fails. Check connectivity, URL, or request configuration.
Occurs if a request exceeds the specified timeout. Adjust timeouts based on network conditions.
Occurs when request parameters (URL, headers, body) are invalid. Validate inputs before sending requests.

Java.name: Retrofit
Java.description: Retrofit is a type-safe HTTP client for Java and Android, developed by Square. It allows you to define REST API endpoints as Java interfaces and automatically converts HTTP responses into Java objects using converters like Gson or Jackson.
Java.story: Retrofit was created by Square to simplify the process of consuming REST APIs in Java applications. By leveraging annotations, it abstracts network calls, handles serialization/deserialization, and supports synchronous and asynchronous requests.

usage.overview: Retrofit allows developers to define API endpoints in Java interfaces, handle requests and responses easily, and integrate with JSON converters. It supports query parameters, path variables, headers, and multipart requests.

basic_examples.title: Defining a simple API interface
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a GET request to fetch a list of users from the `/users` endpoint.

basic_examples.title: Creating Retrofit instance
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a Retrofit instance with a base URL and a Gson converter for JSON parsing.

advanced_examples.title: Making synchronous requests
advanced_examples.explanation: Executes a request synchronously and retrieves the response body.

advanced_examples.title: Making asynchronous requests
advanced_examples.explanation: Executes a request asynchronously using a callback.

advanced_examples.title: Using path and query parameters
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows how to pass dynamic path variables and query parameters in API calls.

advanced_examples.title: Adding headers
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates setting static headers for a specific API request.

best_practices: Reuse Retrofit instances to leverage connection pooling.
Use converters like Gson, Jackson, or Moshi for serialization/deserialization.
Handle errors and HTTP status codes in the callback.
Prefer asynchronous requests for network operations to avoid blocking threads.
Leverage OkHttp interceptors for logging, authentication, and retries.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when a network request fails. Check connectivity and URL.
Thrown when the HTTP response is not successful (non-2xx). Check status code and response body.
Occurs when JSON response cannot be parsed into the specified Java object. Ensure matching fields and types.

Java.name: Feign
Java.description: Feign is a declarative HTTP client for Java, primarily used with Spring Cloud to simplify REST API calls. It allows developers to define API clients using interfaces and annotations.
Java.story: Feign was created by Netflix to provide a type-safe and declarative way to call REST services in Java. It integrates seamlessly with Spring Boot and Spring Cloud, supporting load balancing, circuit breakers, and automatic request/response mapping.

usage.overview: Feign allows developers to define Java interfaces annotated with HTTP methods, paths, and parameters. Spring Boot automatically generates the implementation and handles serialization/deserialization, making API calls simple and readable.

basic_examples.title: Defining a Feign client
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a Feign client interface to fetch a list of users from the `/users` endpoint.

basic_examples.title: Enabling Feign in Spring Boot
basic_examples.explanation: Enables Feign support in a Spring Boot application.

advanced_examples.title: Passing query parameters
advanced_examples.code:
@GetMapping("/users")
List<User> getUsersByRole(@RequestParam("role") String role);
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates sending query parameters in Feign client calls.

advanced_examples.title: Handling path variables
advanced_examples.code:
@GetMapping("/users/{id}")
User getUserById(@PathVariable("id") Long id);
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates sending path variables in Feign client calls.

advanced_examples.title: Custom headers
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows how to pass custom headers dynamically in Feign requests.

advanced_examples.title: Using fallback for error handling
advanced_examples.explanation: Provides a fallback implementation when the Feign client call fails.

best_practices: Use Feign clients as interfaces to improve testability and maintainability.
Leverage Spring Cloud load balancing and resilience features (e.g., Hystrix or Resilience4j) with Feign.
Handle exceptions and fallback responses gracefully.
Prefer declarative annotations over manual HTTP calls for cleaner code.
Use DTOs and proper serialization libraries (Gson, Jackson) for request/response objects.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when the Feign client receives a non-successful HTTP response. Check status code and error body.
Thrown when a 4xx HTTP error occurs. Validate request parameters and headers.
Thrown when a 5xx HTTP error occurs. Retry or use fallback mechanisms for resilience.

Java.name: MapStruct
Java.description: MapStruct is a Java annotation processor for generating type-safe and performant mappers that automatically convert between Java beans (DTOs and entities).
Java.story: MapStruct was created to eliminate the boilerplate code of writing manual mapping logic between Java objects. By generating mapper implementations at compile-time, it ensures type safety, high performance, and easy maintenance.

installation.maven: Add org.mapstruct:mapstruct dependency and mapstruct-processor annotationProcessor in pom.xml
installation.gradle: Add implementation 'org.mapstruct:mapstruct:1.6.14.Final' and annotationProcessor 'org.mapstruct:mapstruct-processor:1.6.14.Final' in build.gradle

usage.overview: MapStruct allows developers to define mapper interfaces annotated with `@Mapper`. At compile-time, MapStruct generates the implementation class for converting between source and target objects.

basic_examples.title: Defining a simple mapper
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a mapper interface for converting a `User` entity to `UserDTO`. MapStruct generates the implementation automatically.

basic_examples.title: Using the mapper
basic_examples.explanation: Uses the generated mapper to convert a `User` object to a `UserDTO` object.

advanced_examples.title: Mapping collections
advanced_examples.code: List<UserDTO> dtos = UserMapper.INSTANCE.usersToUserDTOs(usersList);
advanced_examples.explanation: MapStruct can convert collections of objects automatically.

advanced_examples.title: Custom field mapping
advanced_examples.code:
@Mapping(source = "email", target = "contactEmail")
UserDTO userToUserDTO(User user);
advanced_examples.explanation: Maps fields with different names using `@Mapping` annotation.

advanced_examples.title: Nested object mapping
advanced_examples.code:
@Mapping(source = "address.street", target = "streetName")
UserDTO userToUserDTO(User user);
advanced_examples.explanation: Maps nested fields from source object to target object.

advanced_examples.title: Mapping with expressions
advanced_examples.code:
@Mapping(target = "fullName", expression = "java(user.getFirstName() + ' ' + user.getLastName())")
UserDTO userToUserDTO(User user);
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses Java expressions for complex field transformations during mapping.

best_practices: Keep mapping interfaces simple and modular.
Use `@Mapper` with componentModel = 'spring' for Spring Boot integration.
Prefer compile-time mappings over reflection-based mapping for performance.
Leverage `@Mapping` for fields with different names or types.
Validate mapping results in unit tests to ensure correctness.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when a target field does not have a corresponding mapping. Add `@Mapping` or `@Mappings` annotations or ignore unmapped fields.
Occurs if MapStruct annotation processor is not configured correctly. Ensure proper dependencies and annotationProcessor setup.
Occurs when source and target types cannot be mapped. Use type conversions or custom mapping methods.

Java.name: Lombok
Java.description: Lombok is a Java library that reduces boilerplate code by generating commonly used methods like getters, setters, constructors, `toString`, `equals`, and `hashCode` using annotations.
Java.story: Lombok was created to simplify Java development by automating repetitive coding tasks. It uses annotation processing to generate code at compile-time, keeping the source code clean and readable while maintaining full type safety.

installation.maven: Add org.projectlombok:lombok dependency in pom.xml and enable annotation processing in IDE
installation.gradle: Add implementation 'org.projectlombok:lombok:1.18.30' in build.gradle and enable annotation processing

usage.overview: Lombok provides annotations like `@Getter`, `@Setter`, `@NoArgsConstructor`, `@AllArgsConstructor`, `@Builder`, `@Data`, and more. These annotations automatically generate code during compilation, reducing boilerplate while keeping Java code clean.

basic_examples.title: Using @Getter and @Setter
basic_examples.explanation: Automatically generates getter and setter methods for `id` and `name` fields.

basic_examples.title: Using @NoArgsConstructor and @AllArgsConstructor
basic_examples.explanation: Generates a no-argument constructor and an all-argument constructor automatically.

basic_examples.title: Using @ToString and @EqualsAndHashCode
basic_examples.explanation: Automatically generates `toString()`, `equals()`, and `hashCode()` methods.

advanced_examples.title: Using @Builder
advanced_examples.explanation: Enables the builder pattern for creating instances of `User`.

advanced_examples.title: Using @Data
advanced_examples.explanation: `@Data` generates getters, setters, `toString()`, `equals()`, `hashCode()`, and required constructors in a single annotation.

advanced_examples.title: Using @Value for immutable objects
advanced_examples.explanation: `@Value` creates immutable classes with final fields, getters, `toString()`, `equals()`, `hashCode()`, and a constructor.

advanced_examples.title: Customizing generated methods
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates adding custom annotations or behaviors to generated methods using Lombok features.

best_practices: Use Lombok annotations to reduce boilerplate but avoid overusing `@Data` on entities with sensitive fields.
Enable annotation processing in your IDE for proper code generation.
Combine `@Builder` with `@AllArgsConstructor` for flexible object creation.
Prefer immutable classes (`@Value`) where possible for safer code.
Use `@Getter` and `@Setter` selectively for better control over field access.

error_handling.solution: Ensure annotation processing is enabled in the IDE and Maven/Gradle plugins are configured correctly.

error_handling.error: IDE does not recognize generated methods
error_handling.solution: Rebuild the project or refresh IDE caches; ensure Lombok plugin is installed.

Java.name: SLF4J
Java.description: SLF4J (Simple Logging Facade for Java) is a logging abstraction that allows developers to plug in various logging frameworks such as Logback, Log4j, or java.util.logging without changing application code.
Java.story: SLF4J was created to standardize logging in Java applications. Instead of tying code to a specific logging framework, SLF4J provides a facade that decouples logging API usage from the underlying logging implementation, enabling flexibility and consistency.

installation.maven: Add org.slf4j:slf4j-api dependency in pom.xml and include a binding like ch.qos.logback:logback-classic
installation.gradle: Add implementation 'org.slf4j:slf4j-api:2.0.9' and implementation 'ch.qos.logback:logback-classic:1.4.11' in build.gradle

usage.overview: SLF4J allows developers to write logging code independent of the logging framework. Logging levels like TRACE, DEBUG, INFO, WARN, and ERROR are supported, with support for parameterized messages and exception logging.

basic_examples.title: Creating a logger
basic_examples.explanation: Initializes an SLF4J logger for the class and logs an INFO level message.

basic_examples.title: Logging with parameters
basic_examples.code:
String user = "Alice";
logger.debug("User {} has logged in", user);
basic_examples.explanation: Demonstrates parameterized logging to avoid string concatenation overhead.

advanced_examples.title: Logging exceptions
advanced_examples.explanation: Logs an exception with a message and stack trace.

advanced_examples.title: Using different log levels
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates all standard logging levels in SLF4J.

advanced_examples.title: Externalizing configuration with Logback
advanced_examples.code:
<configuration>
  <appender name="STDOUT" class="ch.qos.logback.core.ConsoleAppender">
    <encoder>
      <pattern>%d{yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss} %-5level %logger{36} - %msg%n</pattern>
    </encoder>
  </appender>
  <root level="debug">
    <appender-ref ref="STDOUT" />
  </root>
</configuration>
advanced_examples.explanation: Configures Logback as the underlying logging framework for SLF4J, including log format and level.

best_practices: Use parameterized logging to improve performance and readability.
Avoid hard-coded logging levels; configure them externally with the logging framework.
Log exceptions with stack traces for easier debugging.
Use class-specific loggers rather than a global logger for better context.
Prefer SLF4J facade over direct dependency on a logging implementation for flexibility.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the SLF4J API and an appropriate binding (like Logback) are included in the classpath.
Ensure only one SLF4J binding is present in the project dependencies.

Java.name: Log4j2
Java.description: Log4j2 is a high-performance, flexible, and reliable logging framework for Java applications. It is the successor to Log4j and provides advanced features such as asynchronous logging, custom log levels, and plugin support.
Java.story: Log4j2 was created by the Apache Software Foundation to address performance and flexibility limitations in Log4j 1.x. It leverages a plugin architecture, supports various appenders and layouts, and provides better performance through asynchronous logging and garbage-free design.

installation.maven: Add org.apache.logging.log4j:log4j-core and org.apache.logging.log4j:log4j-api dependencies in pom.xml
installation.gradle: Add implementation 'org.apache.logging.log4j:log4j-api:2.20.0' and implementation 'org.apache.logging.log4j:log4j-core:2.20.0' in build.gradle

usage.overview: Log4j2 allows developers to log messages at different levels (TRACE, DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR, FATAL). It supports configuration through XML, JSON, YAML, or properties files and integrates with SLF4J for logging abstraction.

basic_examples.title: Creating a logger
basic_examples.explanation: Initializes a Log4j2 logger and logs an INFO level message.

basic_examples.title: Logging with parameters
basic_examples.code:
String user = "Alice";
logger.debug("User {} has logged in", user);
basic_examples.explanation: Shows parameterized logging to avoid string concatenation overhead.

advanced_examples.title: Logging exceptions
advanced_examples.explanation: Logs an exception with a message and stack trace.

advanced_examples.title: Asynchronous logging
advanced_examples.code:
<Configuration status="WARN">
  <Appenders>
    <Async name="AsyncConsole">
      <Console />
    </Async>
  </Appenders>
  <Loggers>
    <Root level="info">
      <AppenderRef ref="AsyncConsole" />
    </Root>
  </Loggers>
</Configuration>
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates asynchronous logging configuration for better performance.

advanced_examples.title: Custom log levels and appenders
advanced_examples.code:
<Logger name="com.example" level="debug" additivity="false">
  <AppenderRef ref="FileAppender" />
</Logger>
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a logger with a specific level and appender for fine-grained control.

advanced_examples.title: Using SLF4J with Log4j2
advanced_examples.explanation: Integrates Log4j2 with SLF4J for logging abstraction.

best_practices: Use asynchronous logging for high-throughput applications.
Externalize configuration in XML, JSON, YAML, or properties files for flexibility.
Use parameterized logging instead of string concatenation for performance.
Organize loggers per package or class for clarity.
Leverage multiple appenders (console, file, rolling file, etc.) for different logging needs.

error_handling.solution: Ensure both log4j-api and log4j-core are present in the classpath.
Check configuration file format and location; Log4j2 may fallback to default configuration if it cannot find the custom config.

Java.name: JUnit 5
Java.description: JUnit 5 is a modern testing framework for Java, designed to write unit and integration tests. It provides a modular architecture, rich annotations, and support for lambda expressions and assertions.
Java.story: JUnit 5 was created to address limitations in JUnit 4 and provide a more flexible, extensible, and powerful testing framework. It consists of three modules: JUnit Platform, JUnit Jupiter, and JUnit Vintage, allowing developers to write modern tests and integrate with build tools and IDEs.

usage.overview: JUnit 5 allows developers to write tests using annotations such as `@Test`, `@BeforeEach`, `@AfterEach`, `@BeforeAll`, `@AfterAll`. It supports assertions, assumptions, parameterized tests, nested tests, and extensions for advanced testing scenarios.

basic_examples.title: Simple test case
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a basic JUnit 5 test that checks if the addition of 2 + 3 equals 5.

basic_examples.title: Setup and teardown
basic_examples.explanation: Demonstrates methods that run before and after each test case for setup and cleanup.

advanced_examples.title: Parameterized test
advanced_examples.explanation: Runs the same test multiple times with different input values.

advanced_examples.title: Testing exceptions
advanced_examples.explanation: Verifies that a specific exception is thrown during execution.

advanced_examples.title: Nested tests
advanced_examples.explanation: Organizes tests hierarchically using nested classes for better readability.

advanced_examples.title: Conditional test execution
advanced_examples.explanation: Runs tests conditionally based on operating system, environment, or custom conditions.

best_practices: Write small, focused test cases for each functionality.
Use parameterized tests to avoid code duplication.
Leverage assertions to validate expected outcomes clearly.
Use `@BeforeEach` and `@AfterEach` for setup/cleanup and `@BeforeAll`/`@AfterAll` for global setup.
Integrate JUnit 5 with build tools like Maven/Gradle for automated testing pipelines.

error_handling.solution: Check assertions and expected results; ensure the test logic matches the intended functionality.
Ensure JUnit 5 dependencies are correctly added and annotation processing is enabled if needed.

Java.name: Mockito
Java.description: Mockito is a popular Java testing framework used to create mock objects for unit testing. It allows developers to simulate the behavior of real objects and verify interactions, enabling isolated and controlled tests.
Java.story: Mockito was created to simplify unit testing in Java by providing an easy-to-use API for mocking dependencies. It allows developers to focus on testing the class under test without needing real implementations of its collaborators.

usage.overview: Mockito allows creating mock objects, stubbing methods, verifying interactions, and capturing arguments. It integrates well with JUnit and supports annotations such as `@Mock`, `@InjectMocks`, and `@Spy` for cleaner test code.

basic_examples.title: Creating a mock object
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a mock List, calls a method, and verifies that the method was invoked with the correct argument.

basic_examples.title: Stubbing method behavior
basic_examples.code:
when(mockedList.get(0)).thenReturn("first");
System.out.println(mockedList.get(0)); // prints 'first'
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a return value for a method when called on a mock object.

advanced_examples.title: Injecting mocks into a class
advanced_examples.explanation: Injects mock dependencies into the class under test automatically using `@InjectMocks`.

advanced_examples.title: Using @Spy for partial mocks
advanced_examples.explanation: Allows calling real methods while still being able to verify interactions or stub certain methods.

advanced_examples.title: Argument captor
advanced_examples.explanation: Captures arguments passed to mock methods for detailed verification.

advanced_examples.title: Verifying number of invocations
advanced_examples.code: verify(mockedList, times(2)).add("one");
advanced_examples.explanation: Verifies that a method was called a specific number of times.

best_practices: Use mocks only for external dependencies, not the class under test.
Prefer `@Mock` and `@InjectMocks` annotations for cleaner tests.
Use `verify` to ensure critical interactions with dependencies.
Keep tests focused and independent; avoid relying on actual implementations of collaborators.
Leverage argument captors to validate the actual data passed to mocks.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when a stubbed method is never called. Remove unused stubs or set Mockito to lenient mode.
Ensure that mock objects are initialized properly using `MockitoAnnotations.openMocks()` or the `@ExtendWith(MockitoExtension.class)` JUnit 5 integration.
Verify that the mock object is created using `mock()` or `@Mock` and not null before use.

Java.name: AssertJ
Java.description: AssertJ is a fluent and rich assertion library for Java that allows developers to write readable and expressive unit test assertions. It provides a wide variety of assertions for core Java types, collections, exceptions, and more.
Java.story: AssertJ was created to improve the readability and expressiveness of assertions in Java tests compared to standard JUnit assertions. Its fluent API allows for clear, chainable, and descriptive assertions, making tests easier to write and maintain.

usage.overview: AssertJ provides a fluent API for assertions, allowing chaining of methods, clear error messages, and a wide range of assertions for objects, collections, maps, exceptions, and more. It integrates seamlessly with JUnit or TestNG.

basic_examples.title: Simple assertions
basic_examples.explanation: Asserts that `result` is equal to 5 and positive using fluent chaining.

basic_examples.title: String assertions
basic_examples.code:
String text = "Hello World";
assertThat(text).startsWith("Hello").endsWith("World").contains("lo Wo");
basic_examples.explanation: Performs multiple string checks in a readable fluent style.

advanced_examples.title: Collection assertions
advanced_examples.code:
List<Integer> numbers = Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3, 4);
assertThat(numbers).hasSize(4).contains(2, 3).doesNotContain(5);
advanced_examples.explanation: Performs assertions on collections including size, contents, and absence of elements.

advanced_examples.title: Exception assertions
advanced_examples.code: assertThatThrownBy(() -> { Integer.parseInt("abc"); }).isInstanceOf(NumberFormatException.class).hasMessageContaining("For input string");
advanced_examples.explanation: Checks that a block of code throws a specific exception with a message containing a given string.

advanced_examples.title: Extracting and asserting on properties
advanced_examples.explanation: Extracts properties from objects in a collection and asserts on their values.

advanced_examples.title: Using soft assertions
advanced_examples.explanation: Allows multiple assertions to be evaluated and reported together without stopping at the first failure.

best_practices: Prefer AssertJ for readable and fluent assertions over standard JUnit assertions.
Use chaining to combine multiple assertions on the same object for clarity.
Leverage collection and property extraction methods for complex data structures.
Use soft assertions when you want to evaluate multiple assertions and report all failures.
Integrate with JUnit 5 or TestNG for seamless test execution.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when the actual value does not meet the expected condition. Check the test logic and input values.
Ensure AssertJ core dependency is included in your project classpath.

Java.name: Testcontainers
Java.description: Testcontainers is a Java library that provides lightweight, disposable Docker containers for running integration tests. It allows developers to test against databases, message brokers, or any containerized service in a reproducible way.
Java.story: Testcontainers was created to simplify integration testing by providing real, isolated environments using Docker containers. It eliminates the need for complex local setup and ensures tests run consistently across different machines and CI environments.

usage.overview: Testcontainers allows developers to spin up Docker containers for databases, message queues, or other services during test execution. It supports JUnit 5 extensions, lifecycle management, reusable containers, and pre-configured modules for common services like PostgreSQL, MySQL, Kafka, and Redis.

Java.description: Micronaut is a modern, JVM-based framework for building modular, easily testable microservices and serverless applications. It emphasizes low memory footprint, fast startup time, and dependency injection with compile-time optimizations.
Java.story: Micronaut was created to address limitations in traditional Java frameworks for microservices and serverless environments. Java.name: Quarkus
Java.description: Quarkus is a Kubernetes-native Java framework designed for building cloud-native, reactive, and serverless applications with fast startup times and low memory footprint.
Java.story: Quarkus was created to optimize Java for containerized environments and serverless deployments. It leverages compile-time boot, GraalVM native image support, and reactive programming to provide a high-performance and developer-friendly framework for modern applications.

Java.name: Apache Kafka
Java.description: Apache Kafka is a distributed streaming platform used for building real-time data pipelines and streaming applications. It provides high-throughput, fault-tolerant, and scalable messaging between producers and consumers.
Java.story: Kafka was originally developed at LinkedIn to handle real-time activity stream data and later became an open-source project under the Apache Software Foundation. It enables applications to process and react to streams of events efficiently and reliably.

usage.overview: Kafka allows developers to produce and consume messages to topics, stream processing using Kafka Streams, and integrate with other systems using Kafka Connect. It supports distributed, fault-tolerant, and scalable messaging architecture.

Java.name: Jersey
Java.description: Jersey is the reference implementation of JAX-RS (Java API for RESTful Web Services) for building RESTful web services in Java. It simplifies creating web services with annotations, dependency injection, and automatic JSON/XML support.
Java.story: Jersey was developed by Oracle (originally as part of GlassFish) to provide a standard, annotation-driven framework for creating RESTful web services on the Java platform. Over the years, Jersey has become a widely used framework in enterprise and microservice applications due to its adherence to standards and ease of integration.

Java.name: MyBatis

Java.name: jOOQ

Java.story: jOOQ was developed to bridge the gap between relational databases and Java by providing a domain-specific language for SQL. Apply Guava utilities like Joiner, Splitter, and CharMatcher for clean string manipulation.
Avoid overusing Guava when standard Java 8+ streams and collections are sufficient.

Guava’s immutable collections and utilities often disallow nulls. Check inputs before adding to collections.

Java.name: Apache Commons Lang
Java.description: Apache Commons Lang provides a host of helper utilities for the java.lang API, making everyday Java development easier. It includes functionality for String manipulation, object reflection, concurrency, number handling, date/time, and more.
Java.story: Commons Lang was created to fill the gaps in the standard Java library by providing reusable, well-tested, and reliable utilities. It simplifies common tasks such as string manipulation, reflection, object comparison, and exception handling, improving productivity and code readability. It is widely used in enterprise Java applications and open-source projects.

usage.overview: Commons Lang offers utilities for String operations, Object utilities, Number utilities, Reflection, Builders, Random generation, concurrency helpers, and more. It reduces boilerplate and simplifies common coding patterns.

basic_examples.title: StringUtils example
basic_examples.explanation: Uses StringUtils to trim whitespace and check for empty strings.

basic_examples.title: ObjectUtils example
basic_examples.explanation: Provides a default value when the object is null.

advanced_examples.title: RandomStringUtils
advanced_examples.explanation: Generates a random alphanumeric string of length 10.

advanced_examples.title: ReflectionUtils
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses reflection to read and write private fields.

advanced_examples.title: Compare and Hash
advanced_examples.explanation: Simplifies implementing equals() and hashCode() using builders.

advanced_examples.title: DateUtils example
advanced_examples.explanation: Truncates the time component of a Date to the start of the day.

best_practices: Use StringUtils for null-safe string operations instead of manually checking nulls.
Leverage ObjectUtils and ArrayUtils for handling nulls and defaults.
Use builder classes for equals(), hashCode(), and toString() implementations.
Utilize DateUtils and DurationFormatUtils for date/time operations.
Avoid reinventing common utilities that Commons Lang already provides.

error_handling.solution: Use null-safe methods like StringUtils.isEmpty(), ObjectUtils.defaultIfNull(), etc.
Occurs when input parameters are invalid. Validate inputs before using utility methods.

Java.name: Apache Commons IO
Java.description: Apache Commons IO provides utilities for working with Java I/O, including file and directory manipulation, file filters, input/output stream handling, and file monitoring. It simplifies common I/O operations and reduces boilerplate code.
Java.story: Commons IO was created to provide a robust set of tools for file, stream, and directory operations in Java. It includes classes to copy files, read/write content, monitor directories, apply filters, and work with streams efficiently. It is widely used in Java applications where I/O operations are frequent and complex, making code cleaner and safer.

usage.overview: Commons IO provides utilities for file operations (copy, move, delete), directory traversal, filters, input/output streams, and monitoring. It helps avoid manual boilerplate code for common I/O tasks.

basic_examples.title: Copying a file
basic_examples.explanation: Copies a file from source to destination.

basic_examples.title: Reading file content
basic_examples.code:
String content = FileUtils.readFileToString(new File("example.txt"), "UTF-8");
System.out.println(content);
basic_examples.explanation: Reads the entire content of a file as a String.

advanced_examples.title: Directory traversal
advanced_examples.explanation: Lists all files with specified extensions in a directory recursively.

advanced_examples.title: File monitoring
advanced_examples.explanation: Monitors a directory for changes using FileAlterationMonitor.

advanced_examples.title: Stream utilities
advanced_examples.explanation: Reads the content of an InputStream into a String safely using IOUtils.

advanced_examples.title: Deleting directories
advanced_examples.code: FileUtils.deleteDirectory(new File("/path/to/delete"));
advanced_examples.explanation: Recursively deletes a directory and its contents.

best_practices: Use FileUtils and IOUtils to reduce boilerplate and improve readability.
Always close streams or use try-with-resources to avoid resource leaks.
Use FileAlterationMonitor for efficient directory monitoring instead of polling manually.
Validate paths before performing delete or write operations to prevent accidental data loss.
Combine Commons IO with NIO2 APIs for performance-critical applications.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when file or stream operations fail. Ensure paths exist, have correct permissions, and streams are properly handled.
Thrown when invalid arguments like null files are passed. Validate inputs before calling utility methods.

Java.name: Apache Commons Collections
Java.description: Apache Commons Collections extends the Java Collections Framework with additional interfaces, implementations, and utilities for manipulating and transforming collections. It includes features like Bag, MultiMap, BidiMap, and advanced iterators.
Java.story: Commons Collections was developed to provide powerful, reusable collection utilities beyond the standard Java Collections Framework. It simplifies tasks such as grouping, counting, bidirectional mapping, transforming, and filtering collections. It is widely used in enterprise Java applications, open-source projects, and frameworks that need enhanced collection handling.

usage.overview: Commons Collections provides enhanced collection types like Bag, MultiMap, BidiMap, and utilities for transforming, filtering, and decorating collections. It also offers specialized iterators and predicates for collection manipulation.

basic_examples.title: Bag example
basic_examples.explanation: A Bag counts the occurrences of each element in the collection.

basic_examples.title: MultiMap example
basic_examples.explanation: Stores multiple values for a single key.

advanced_examples.title: BidiMap example
advanced_examples.explanation: Allows bidirectional lookup between keys and values.

advanced_examples.title: Transforming collections
advanced_examples.explanation: Transforms all elements in a collection using a function.

advanced_examples.title: Filtering collections
advanced_examples.explanation: Selects elements from a collection based on a predicate.

advanced_examples.title: LazyList example
advanced_examples.explanation: Creates a list that generates default elements lazily when accessed.

best_practices: Use Bag for counting occurrences instead of manual maps.
Use MultiMap for key-to-multiple-values mappings.
Use BidiMap for two-way lookup between keys and values.
Use CollectionUtils for transformations, filtering, and null-safe operations.
Avoid overusing legacy iterators when Java 8 streams provide equivalent functionality.

error_handling.solution: Ensure collections are initialized and predicates are not null.
Occurs when modifying immutable collections. Use modifiable variants or decorators.

Java.name: Apache Commons Configuration
Java.description: Apache Commons Configuration provides a unified API for accessing configuration data from various sources, including properties files, XML, INI, JSON, and databases. It supports hierarchical configurations, automatic reloading, and combined configuration sources.
Java.story: Commons Configuration was created to simplify managing configuration data in Java applications. It abstracts the details of different configuration formats, allowing developers to read, write, and monitor configurations consistently. Features like hierarchical structures, interpolated variables, and reloading strategies make it ideal for enterprise and complex applications where configuration management is critical.

usage.overview: Commons Configuration allows reading and writing configurations from multiple sources, combining different sources, handling hierarchical data, and monitoring changes. It supports properties, XML, JSON, INI, database-backed configurations, and more.

basic_examples.title: Loading a properties file
basic_examples.explanation: Loads a properties file and reads a configuration value.

basic_examples.title: Reading an XML configuration
basic_examples.explanation: Reads a value from an XML configuration file.

advanced_examples.title: Hierarchical configuration
advanced_examples.explanation: Accesses a subsection of a hierarchical configuration.

advanced_examples.title: Combining multiple configuration sources
advanced_examples.explanation: Combines multiple configuration sources into one unified view.

advanced_examples.title: Automatic reloading
advanced_examples.explanation: Sets up automatic reloading of a properties file every 5 seconds.

advanced_examples.title: Interpolated values
advanced_examples.explanation: Supports variable interpolation within configuration values.

best_practices: Use CompositeConfiguration to merge multiple configuration sources cleanly.
Use hierarchical configurations for structured data like XML or JSON.
Leverage automatic reloading to update configuration without restarting the application.
Validate configuration values during startup to catch errors early.
Keep sensitive configuration (like passwords) in secure sources or environment variables.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when a configuration file cannot be read or parsed. Check file paths, syntax, and permissions.
Occurs when attempting to access a missing configuration key. Use getString with a default value or validate keys.

Java.name: Google Guice
Java.description: Google Guice is a lightweight dependency injection framework for Java. It allows you to manage object creation and dependencies declaratively using annotations, reducing boilerplate and promoting loose coupling.
Java.story: Guice was created by Google to simplify dependency management in Java applications. Instead of manually instantiating objects and passing dependencies, Guice allows developers to define how objects are wired together using modules and annotations like @Inject. It supports scopes, providers, and AOP features, making it suitable for both small and enterprise applications.

usage.overview: Guice provides a declarative way to bind interfaces to implementations and inject dependencies. It supports constructor, method, and field injection, scopes (singleton, request, etc.), providers, and AOP interceptors.

basic_examples.title: Basic dependency injection
basic_examples.explanation: Binds the Service interface to ServiceImpl and injects it into Client automatically.

basic_examples.title: Field injection
basic_examples.explanation: Demonstrates injecting dependencies directly into fields.

advanced_examples.title: Using Providers
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses Provider to lazily fetch instances of a dependency when needed.

advanced_examples.title: Singleton scope
advanced_examples.code: binder.bind(Service.class).to(ServiceImpl.class).in(Singleton.class);
advanced_examples.explanation: Ensures a single instance of ServiceImpl is shared across the application.

advanced_examples.title: Custom module
advanced_examples.explanation: Organizes bindings in a module for cleaner configuration.

advanced_examples.title: Method injection
advanced_examples.explanation: Injects dependencies using a setter method.

best_practices: Prefer constructor injection over field or method injection for better testability.
Use Modules to centralize and manage bindings cleanly.
Leverage Singleton scope for stateless or shared services to save resources.
Use Providers for lazy or conditional dependency creation.
Combine Guice with AOP for cross-cutting concerns like logging and transactions.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when bindings are missing or ambiguous. Ensure all required bindings are properly defined.
Occurs when Guice fails to create an instance. Check for constructor exceptions or circular dependencies.

Java.name: Apache HttpClient
Java.description: Apache HttpClient is a robust and feature-rich HTTP client library for Java. It allows sending HTTP requests, handling responses, managing connections, cookies, authentication, and supporting advanced features like redirects and timeouts.
Java.story: HttpClient was created to simplify HTTP communication in Java applications. It abstracts the complexities of HTTP connections, supports synchronous and asynchronous operations, and provides utilities for headers, cookies, and authentication. Widely used in web services, REST clients, and integrations, it ensures reliable and maintainable HTTP communication.

usage.overview: HttpClient allows creating HTTP requests (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE), handling responses, managing cookies, setting headers, handling timeouts, and supporting connection pooling. It supports both synchronous and asynchronous request execution.

basic_examples.title: Simple GET request
basic_examples.explanation: Performs a simple GET request and prints the response content.

basic_examples.title: Simple POST request
basic_examples.explanation: Sends a POST request with JSON payload and prints the response.

advanced_examples.title: Custom headers
advanced_examples.explanation: Adds custom headers to the request.

advanced_examples.title: Handling timeouts
advanced_examples.explanation: Sets a timeout to prevent indefinite waiting.

advanced_examples.title: Using connection pool
advanced_examples.explanation: Manages multiple HTTP connections efficiently using a connection pool.

advanced_examples.title: Basic authentication
advanced_examples.explanation: Sets up basic authentication for requests.

best_practices: Use connection pooling for high-performance applications.
Always set timeouts to avoid hanging requests.
Use fluent API for simpler code and readability.
Handle exceptions like IOExceptions to ensure reliability.
Close resources properly using try-with-resources or clients’ close() methods.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when there is a network error or server is unreachable. Handle exceptions appropriately.
Occurs when the response status code indicates an error. Check status code and handle accordingly.
Occurs when connections cannot be acquired from the pool. Adjust pool size or release connections promptly.

Java.name: OkHttp
Java.description: OkHttp is a modern, efficient, and feature-rich HTTP client for Java and Android. It supports synchronous and asynchronous requests, connection pooling, HTTP/2, web sockets, caching, retries, and timeouts.
Java.story: OkHttp was developed by Square to simplify HTTP communication in Java and Android applications. It provides a high-performance and reliable client with advanced features like transparent GZIP compression, connection reuse, and support for modern protocols like HTTP/2 and WebSocket. OkHttp is widely used in REST clients, microservices, and mobile applications.

usage.overview: OkHttp allows creating HTTP requests (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE), handling responses, managing headers and cookies, performing asynchronous calls, and integrating with web sockets and interceptors.

basic_examples.title: Simple GET request
basic_examples.explanation: Performs a synchronous GET request and prints the response body.

basic_examples.title: Simple POST request
basic_examples.explanation: Sends a POST request with a JSON payload.

advanced_examples.title: Asynchronous request
advanced_examples.explanation: Executes the request asynchronously without blocking the main thread.

advanced_examples.title: Adding headers
advanced_examples.code:
Request request = new Request.Builder()
    .url("https://httpbin.org/headers")
    .addHeader("User-Agent", "OkHttpClient/1.0")
    .build();
advanced_examples.explanation: Adds custom headers to an HTTP request.

advanced_examples.title: Connection pooling
advanced_examples.explanation: Manages reusable connections to improve performance.

advanced_examples.title: Timeouts
advanced_examples.code:
OkHttpClient client = new OkHttpClient.Builder()
    .connectTimeout(10, TimeUnit.SECONDS)
    .readTimeout(30, TimeUnit.SECONDS)
    .writeTimeout(15, TimeUnit.SECONDS)
    .build();
advanced_examples.explanation: Sets connection, read, and write timeouts to prevent hanging requests.

advanced_examples.title: WebSocket usage
advanced_examples.explanation: Connects to a WebSocket endpoint and sends/receives messages.

best_practices: Reuse OkHttpClient instances to take advantage of connection pooling.
Use asynchronous requests to avoid blocking the main thread in applications.
Set timeouts to prevent network delays from hanging the application.
Use interceptors for logging, authentication, or modifying requests/responses.
Close response bodies to prevent resource leaks.

error_handling.solution: Occurs for network failures or server errors. Handle exceptions appropriately with retries if needed.
Occurs when the server response violates HTTP protocol. Ensure requests and server responses are valid.
Occurs if the request body or response is used improperly. Always follow OkHttp usage rules.

Java.name: Jakarta Mail (JavaMail)
Java.description: Jakarta Mail (formerly JavaMail) is a Java API for sending, receiving, and managing email messages using protocols such as SMTP, IMAP, and POP3. It provides a simple interface for building email applications and integrating email functionality into Java applications.
Java.story: JavaMail was originally developed as part of the Java EE platform and later moved to the Eclipse Foundation under Jakarta EE. It abstracts the complexities of email protocols, allowing developers to focus on application logic. Jakarta Mail is widely used in enterprise applications, automated email notifications, and email clients.

usage.overview: Jakarta Mail allows sending emails via SMTP, reading emails from IMAP or POP3, handling attachments, multipart messages, HTML content, and managing folders. It integrates easily with Java SE and Jakarta EE applications.

best_practices: Use SSL/TLS for secure email transmission.
Reuse Session objects instead of creating new ones repeatedly.
Handle exceptions like MessagingException and IOException gracefully.
Close connections, folders, and stores properly to avoid resource leaks.
Validate email addresses before sending to prevent delivery failures.

Java.name: Flyway
Java.description: Flyway is an open-source database migration tool for Java that allows developers to version, manage, and automate database schema changes. It supports SQL-based migrations as well as Java-based migrations for complex transformations.
Java.story: Flyway was created to simplify database version control and continuous integration workflows. It enables developers to maintain consistent database schemas across environments, ensures smooth migrations, and integrates easily with Java applications and build tools. Flyway is widely used in enterprise applications, microservices, and automated deployment pipelines.

usage.overview: Flyway allows defining migrations as SQL scripts or Java classes, tracks which migrations have been applied, and ensures the database is up-to-date. It supports multiple databases such as PostgreSQL, MySQL, Oracle, SQL Server, and SQLite.

basic_examples.title: Basic Flyway configuration
basic_examples.explanation: Configures Flyway with a PostgreSQL database and applies all pending migrations.

basic_examples.title: SQL-based migration
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a SQL migration script named with Flyway's versioned naming convention (V1__).

advanced_examples.title: Java-based migration
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a Java-based migration to add a column to the users table.

advanced_examples.title: Undo migration
advanced_examples.code:
-- U2__remove_email_from_users.sql
ALTER TABLE users DROP COLUMN email;
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines an undo migration script to revert a previous migration if needed.

advanced_examples.title: Baseline an existing database
advanced_examples.explanation: Sets a baseline for an existing database to start managing migrations without reapplying old scripts.

best_practices: Use versioned migrations (V1__, V2__, ...) for schema changes to maintain order.
Keep SQL scripts small and atomic to reduce risks during migrations.
Store migration scripts in source control alongside application code.
Test migrations in a staging environment before production deployment.
Use Java-based migrations only when complex logic or conditional operations are required.

error_handling.solution: Occurs if a migration fails or the database is in an inconsistent state. Inspect migration logs and fix the SQL/Java scripts.
Occurs when the applied migrations do not match the migration history. Use repair() cautiously to fix metadata.
Occurs for database-level errors. Check connection settings, SQL syntax, and database compatibility.

Java.name: RxJava
Java.description: RxJava is a Java library for composing asynchronous and event-based programs using observable sequences. It provides powerful operators for managing concurrency, data streams, and transformations in a functional style.
Java.story: RxJava was inspired by the Reactive Extensions (Rx) from Microsoft and was created to bring reactive programming paradigms to Java. It allows developers to handle asynchronous events, multithreading, and reactive streams in a declarative way, improving code readability and reducing boilerplate in complex event-driven applications.

usage.overview: RxJava provides Observable, Flowable, Single, Maybe, and Completable types to handle streams of data. It supports operators like map, filter, merge, flatMap, and error handling operators for reactive programming patterns.

basic_examples.title: Creating an Observable
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a simple Observable that emits three strings and prints them.

basic_examples.title: Using map operator
basic_examples.code:
Observable<Integer> numbers = Observable.just(1, 2, 3, 4);
numbers.map(x -> x * x).subscribe(System.out::println);
basic_examples.explanation: Transforms each emitted number by squaring it using the map operator.

advanced_examples.title: Combining Observables
advanced_examples.explanation: Combines the latest emissions from two Observables.

advanced_examples.title: Error handling
advanced_examples.code:
Observable<Integer> numbers = Observable.just(1, 0, 2);
numbers.map(x -> 10 / x).onErrorReturnItem(-1).subscribe(System.out::println);
advanced_examples.explanation: Handles division by zero errors and provides a default value using onErrorReturnItem.

advanced_examples.title: Using Flowable for backpressure
advanced_examples.explanation: Handles large streams of data efficiently with Flowable to manage backpressure.

advanced_examples.title: Threading with Schedulers
advanced_examples.code:
Observable.just("Hello", "RxJava")
    .subscribeOn(Schedulers.io())
    .observeOn(Schedulers.single())
    .subscribe(System.out::println);
advanced_examples.explanation: Specifies different threads for subscription and observation using Schedulers.

best_practices: Use appropriate reactive types (Observable, Flowable, Single, Maybe, Completable) for the scenario.
Always manage subscriptions to avoid memory leaks, using Disposable or CompositeDisposable.
Use Flowable for streams with large or fast-emitting data to handle backpressure.
Prefer functional operators over manual threading and callbacks for cleaner code.
Handle errors explicitly using onErrorReturn, onErrorResumeNext, or try-catch in operators.

error_handling.solution: Occurs if an Observable emits an error but no error handler is provided. Always provide onError callbacks when subscribing.
Occurs when Flowable emits items faster than downstream can consume. Use strategies like buffer, drop, or latest to manage backpressure.
RxJava does not allow null emissions. Ensure that no null values are emitted in the stream.

Java.name: Project Reactor
Java.description: Project Reactor is a reactive library for building non-blocking, asynchronous, and event-driven applications on the JVM. It provides types like Mono and Flux to handle zero-to-one and zero-to-many reactive sequences respectively, following the Reactive Streams specification.
Java.story: Project Reactor was developed by Pivotal (now part of VMware) to provide a fully reactive foundation for Java applications, particularly in Spring ecosystems. It is widely used in reactive web applications, microservices, and data streaming pipelines to improve scalability, responsiveness, and resource utilization.

usage.overview: Project Reactor provides reactive types like Flux and Mono, operators for transformations, filtering, combining, error handling, and scheduling. It integrates seamlessly with Spring WebFlux and reactive databases for end-to-end non-blocking applications.

basic_examples.title: Creating a Mono
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a Mono that emits a single value and prints it.

basic_examples.title: Creating a Flux
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a Flux that emits multiple values and prints each one.

advanced_examples.title: Transforming data with map
advanced_examples.code:
Flux<Integer> numbers = Flux.just(1, 2, 3, 4);
numbers.map(x -> x * x).subscribe(System.out::println);
advanced_examples.explanation: Applies a transformation to each emitted value using the map operator.

advanced_examples.title: Filtering data
advanced_examples.code:
Flux<Integer> numbers = Flux.range(1, 10);
numbers.filter(x -> x % 2 == 0).subscribe(System.out::println);
advanced_examples.explanation: Filters even numbers from a sequence using the filter operator.

advanced_examples.title: Combining sequences
advanced_examples.explanation: Combines two sequences element-wise using zip.

advanced_examples.title: Error handling
advanced_examples.code:
Flux<Integer> numbers = Flux.just(1, 0, 2);
numbers.map(x -> 10 / x).onErrorReturn(-1).subscribe(System.out::println);
advanced_examples.explanation: Handles division by zero errors and provides a fallback value.

advanced_examples.title: Scheduling and threading
advanced_examples.code:
Flux.range(1, 5)
    .publishOn(Schedulers.parallel())
    .map(x -> x * 2)
    .subscribe(System.out::println);
advanced_examples.explanation: Executes the Flux operations on a parallel scheduler for non-blocking concurrency.

best_practices: Use Mono for single-value sequences and Flux for multiple-value sequences.
Avoid blocking calls inside reactive pipelines to maintain non-blocking behavior.
Handle errors gracefully with onErrorReturn, onErrorResume, or retry operators.
Use proper Schedulers for asynchronous execution and resource management.
Integrate with Spring WebFlux or reactive database clients for end-to-end reactive applications.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when a reactive stream emits an error but no error handler is defined. Always provide onError handlers.
Occurs when subscribing multiple times to a single-use Mono or Flux improperly. Ensure proper usage.
Reactor does not allow null values to be emitted. Use Mono.empty() or Flux.empty() instead of null.

Java.name: RabbitMQ Java Client
Java.description: RabbitMQ Java Client is a Java library for interacting with RabbitMQ, a message broker that implements the Advanced Message Queuing Protocol (AMQP). It enables applications to send, receive, and process messages asynchronously and reliably.
Java.story: RabbitMQ, originally developed by Pivotal, is a popular message broker used in distributed systems, microservices, and event-driven architectures. The Java client allows developers to integrate RabbitMQ messaging capabilities into Java applications, supporting features like queues, exchanges, routing, acknowledgments, and transactions for reliable message delivery.

usage.overview: The library provides ConnectionFactory, Connection, Channel, and QueueingConsumer APIs to connect to RabbitMQ, declare queues, publish and consume messages, and manage exchanges and routing keys.

basic_examples.title: Sending a message
basic_examples.explanation: Connects to RabbitMQ, declares a queue, and sends a simple message.

advanced_examples.title: Acknowledgments and manual message handling
advanced_examples.explanation: Handles messages manually and acknowledges after processing to ensure reliability.

advanced_examples.code:

channel.basicPublish("", "task_queue", props, message.getBytes());
advanced_examples.explanation: Marks messages as persistent to survive RabbitMQ restarts.

best_practices: Use persistent messages for critical data that should survive broker restarts.
Handle message acknowledgments properly to avoid message loss or duplication.
Use appropriate exchange types (direct, fanout, topic, headers) based on routing requirements.
Monitor queues and consumers to prevent bottlenecks and memory issues.
Use connection pooling or shared connections for efficiency in high-throughput systems.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when network or connection issues happen. Ensure RabbitMQ server is running and reachable.
Occurs when connections or operations exceed timeout. Adjust timeout settings or check network stability.
Occurs when the connection or channel is closed unexpectedly. Handle reconnections gracefully.

Java.name: ActiveMQ
Java.description: Apache ActiveMQ is a popular open-source message broker that implements JMS (Java Message Service). The ActiveMQ Java Client library allows Java applications to send, receive, and process messages asynchronously and reliably across distributed systems.
Java.story: ActiveMQ was created by the Apache Software Foundation to provide a robust, high-performance, and enterprise-grade messaging solution. It supports a wide variety of messaging patterns, protocols, and integrations, making it suitable for microservices, event-driven systems, and enterprise applications.

usage.overview: ActiveMQ Java Client provides ConnectionFactory, Connection, Session, MessageProducer, MessageConsumer, Queue, and Topic APIs to facilitate message sending, receiving, and management. It supports both point-to-point (queue) and publish-subscribe (topic) messaging models.

basic_examples.title: Receiving a message from a queue
basic_examples.explanation: Connects to ActiveMQ, listens on a queue, and prints received messages.
