JavaScript.name: Redux
JavaScript.description: Redux is a predictable state container for JavaScript apps. It helps manage application state in a single store, enabling easier debugging, testing, and predictable behavior across the app.
JavaScript.story: Redux was created by Dan Abramov and Andrew Clark in 2015. It was inspired by Flux but simplified the architecture, emphasizing a single immutable state tree and pure reducers. Redux became widely adopted for complex React applications to manage state consistently.

installation.cdn: <script src='https://unpkg.com/redux/dist/redux.min.js'></script>
installation.manual: Download the Redux package from npm or the GitHub repository and include it in your project.

usage.overview: Redux uses a single store to hold the entire state of the application. State changes are made via actions and handled by pure reducer functions. Middleware can extend Redux with additional capabilities like async actions.

basic_examples.title: Creating a simple store
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a Redux store with an initial state and a simple reducer that handles an INCREMENT action.

basic_examples.title: Dispatching actions
basic_examples.code:
store.dispatch({ type: 'INCREMENT' });
console.log(store.getState());
basic_examples.explanation: Dispatches an action to update the state and prints the new state.

advanced_examples.title: Using middleware (Redux Thunk)
advanced_examples.explanation: Adds asynchronous action handling using Redux Thunk middleware.

advanced_examples.title: Combining reducers
advanced_examples.explanation: Combines multiple reducers into a single root reducer for managing different parts of the state.

advanced_examples.title: Subscribing to state changes
advanced_examples.code:
store.subscribe(() => console.log('State updated:', store.getState()));
store.dispatch({ type: 'INCREMENT' });
advanced_examples.explanation: Registers a listener to run whenever the state changes.

best_practices: Keep state normalized and avoid nested structures when possible.
Use action creators to encapsulate action creation logic.
Keep reducers pure and free of side effects.
Use middleware for async actions instead of placing side effects in reducers.
Use Redux DevTools for debugging and inspecting state changes.

error_handling.solution: Ensure that reducers return a new state object instead of mutating the existing state.
Check that middleware is applied correctly using `applyMiddleware` when creating the store.
Ensure the action type matches what your reducer is handling.

JavaScript.name: Zustand
JavaScript.description: Zustand is a small, fast, and scalable state management library for React. It provides a simple API to create global state stores with minimal boilerplate, using hooks for accessing and updating state.
JavaScript.story: Zustand was created by Jotai and React community contributors to offer an alternative to heavier state management libraries like Redux. It emphasizes simplicity, ease of use, and minimalistic design while being highly performant and flexible for both small and large applications.

usage.overview: Zustand allows you to create a store that holds your global state. Components can read from and write to the store using hooks. It supports derived state, middleware, and persistence without forcing a specific architecture.

basic_examples.title: Creating a simple store
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a store with a `count` state and functions to increment and decrement it.

basic_examples.title: Using the store in a component
basic_examples.explanation: Accesses state and actions from the store inside a React component.

advanced_examples.title: Derived state
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates creating derived values from the store’s state.

advanced_examples.title: Middleware example
advanced_examples.explanation: Adds persistence to the store so state is saved in localStorage.

advanced_examples.title: Combining multiple actions
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows multiple actions including parameterized state updates and resetting state.

best_practices: Use small, focused stores for different concerns rather than one large global store.
Leverage hooks to read only the parts of state needed by a component to avoid unnecessary re-renders.
Use middleware like `persist` or `redux-devtools-extension` for debugging and persistence.
Keep state updates immutable even though Zustand allows direct mutation in set functions.
Encapsulate complex logic inside actions rather than inside components.

error_handling.solution: Ensure you are using the hook returned by the store and not a stale reference. Destructure state inside the component.
Split state into multiple smaller stores and select only needed slices with hooks.
Check that the `persist` middleware is correctly applied and browser localStorage is accessible.

JavaScript.name: Recoil
JavaScript.description: Recoil is a state management library for React that provides a simple and flexible way to share state across components. It allows for fine-grained state updates, derived state, and asynchronous selectors while integrating seamlessly with React's concurrent features.
JavaScript.story: Recoil was developed by Facebook to address complex state management needs in React applications. It introduces atoms (pieces of state) and selectors (derived or computed state), providing a more declarative and scalable approach compared to prop drilling or using large global stores.

usage.overview: Recoil uses atoms to represent shared state and selectors to derive or transform state. Components subscribe to atoms or selectors via hooks, automatically re-rendering when state changes. It supports both synchronous and asynchronous derived state.

basic_examples.title: Creating an atom
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a Recoil atom representing a piece of state called `countState` with a default value of 0.

basic_examples.title: Using an atom in a component
basic_examples.explanation: Uses the `useRecoilState` hook to read and update the `countState` atom in a React component.

advanced_examples.title: Derived state with selectors
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a selector that derives a new piece of state (`doubleCountState`) based on the value of `countState`.

advanced_examples.title: Using an async selector
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows how to define a selector that fetches data asynchronously.

advanced_examples.title: Multiple atoms and selectors
advanced_examples.explanation: Combines multiple atoms into a derived state (full name) using a selector.

best_practices: Use atoms for shared state and selectors for derived or computed state.
Keep atoms small and focused to avoid unnecessary re-renders.
Use unique `key` values for all atoms and selectors.
Leverage asynchronous selectors for data fetching and caching.
Avoid excessive use of global atoms; local component state is sometimes simpler.

error_handling.solution: Ensure that every atom or selector has a unique `key` string.
Check that you are using Recoil hooks (`useRecoilState`, `useRecoilValue`) and not React state for the same value.
Handle errors in async selectors using try/catch and consider fallback states.

JavaScript.name: MobX
JavaScript.description: MobX is a simple, scalable, and battle-tested state management library for JavaScript applications. It allows you to manage application state outside of components while keeping your UI automatically in sync with state changes.
JavaScript.story: MobX was created by Michel Weststrate to provide a reactive state management solution that is less verbose and more intuitive than Redux. It leverages observables and derivations to automatically update UI components when state changes, reducing boilerplate and promoting a reactive programming paradigm.

usage.overview: MobX uses observables to hold state, actions to modify state, and reactions or observers to automatically update the UI. Computed values allow derived state to be calculated efficiently. MobX integrates seamlessly with React via the `observer` higher-order component or hooks.

basic_examples.title: Creating an observable store
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a store with observable state and actions. `makeAutoObservable` automatically makes state observable and actions reactive.

basic_examples.title: Using MobX store in a React component
basic_examples.explanation: Wraps the component with `observer` so it re-renders automatically when `counterStore.count` changes.

advanced_examples.title: Computed values
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a computed value `total` that automatically recalculates when `items` change.

advanced_examples.title: Reaction example
advanced_examples.explanation: Sets up a reaction that triggers a callback whenever `cartStore.total` changes.

advanced_examples.title: Asynchronous actions
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates performing asynchronous operations safely with MobX using `runInAction`.

best_practices: Use small, focused stores to manage state for different parts of the app.
Wrap React components with `observer` to automatically update UI when observables change.
Use `computed` for derived state to optimize performance.
Avoid directly mutating observables outside of actions for predictable behavior.
Leverage MobX DevTools for debugging and inspecting state changes.

error_handling.solution: Ensure components using observables are wrapped with `observer` or use `useObserver` hook.
Enable `enforceActions` and make all state modifications inside actions.
Make sure computed properties access observable state and are not dependent on non-observable values.

JavaScript.name: Jotai
JavaScript.description: Jotai is a primitive and flexible state management library for React. It provides atoms as units of state, allowing fine-grained control over state updates without the boilerplate of larger libraries like Redux.
JavaScript.story: Jotai was created by Daishi Kato to offer a minimalistic alternative for React state management. Its design emphasizes simplicity, direct usage of React hooks, and a focus on atomic state, where each atom represents an independent piece of state.

usage.overview: Jotai uses atoms to define pieces of state. Components subscribe to atoms using the `useAtom` hook, automatically re-rendering when the atom’s value changes. Derived atoms allow computed state and asynchronous operations.

basic_examples.title: Creating and using an atom
basic_examples.explanation: Defines an atom `countAtom` with an initial value of 0 and uses `useAtom` to read and update the state in a component.

advanced_examples.title: Derived atom
advanced_examples.explanation: Creates a derived atom `doubleCountAtom` that computes its value from another atom.

advanced_examples.title: Async atom
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates an asynchronous atom that fetches data from an API and makes it available to components.

advanced_examples.title: Updating multiple atoms
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows a writable derived atom `fullNameAtom` that updates multiple underlying atoms when set.

best_practices: Keep atoms small and focused for better performance and reusability.
Use derived atoms for computed state instead of duplicating logic in components.
Handle asynchronous operations with async atoms or separate utility functions.
Avoid unnecessary re-renders by subscribing components only to the atoms they need.
Use `atomWithStorage` for persisting state in localStorage or sessionStorage.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the component is using the `useAtom` hook and subscribing to the correct atom.
Check that the derived atom properly reads from its dependencies using `get`.
Handle errors inside the async function or use `atomWithQuery` from Jotai utilities for safer async state.

JavaScript.name: React Router
JavaScript.description: React Router is a standard library for routing in React applications. It enables navigation among views, allows changing the browser URL, and keeps the UI in sync with the URL.
JavaScript.story: React Router was created by Ryan Florence and Michael Jackson in 2014 to solve the problem of handling navigation in single-page React applications. It provides declarative routing components, nested routes, and dynamic route matching, making it easier to manage application state and navigation.

usage.overview: React Router uses components like `<BrowserRouter>`, `<Routes>`, `<Route>`, and `<Link>` to define routes and navigation. It supports dynamic route parameters, nested routes, redirects, and route guards.

basic_examples.title: Setting up basic routes
basic_examples.explanation: Sets up a basic router with two routes (`/` and `/about`) and links for navigation.

basic_examples.title: Using route parameters
basic_examples.explanation: Demonstrates using dynamic route parameters with `useParams` hook.

advanced_examples.title: Nested routes
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows how to define nested routes within a parent route.

advanced_examples.title: Redirects using Navigate
advanced_examples.code:
import { Navigate } from 'react-router-dom';
<Route path='/old' element={<Navigate to='/new' replace />} />
advanced_examples.explanation: Redirects from `/old` to `/new` using the `Navigate` component.

advanced_examples.title: Protected routes
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates guarding routes based on authentication status.

best_practices: Use `<BrowserRouter>` at the root of your app for client-side routing.
Keep route paths consistent and semantic for better readability and SEO.
Use `useParams`, `useLocation`, and `useNavigate` hooks for dynamic route handling.
Prefer nested routes for hierarchical UI structures.
Use `Navigate` for redirects and route guards.

error_handling.solution: Use a wildcard route (`*`) at the end of `<Routes>` to render a 404 component.
Ensure the path in `<Route>` matches the URL exactly, considering trailing slashes.
Wrap your app in `<BrowserRouter>` and use `<Link>` or `useNavigate` for navigation instead of `<a>` tags.

JavaScript.name: Vue Router
JavaScript.description: Vue Router is the official router for Vue.js, enabling navigation between components and views in a Vue application. It provides declarative routing, nested routes, dynamic route matching, and navigation guards.
JavaScript.story: Vue Router was created by the Vue.js core team to handle routing in single-page applications (SPAs). It integrates tightly with Vue's reactive system, allowing developers to easily manage navigation, URL parameters, and programmatic routing with minimal setup.

usage.overview: Vue Router allows you to define routes mapping URLs to components. You can use `<router-link>` for navigation and `<router-view>` to render the matched component. It supports nested routes, dynamic segments, programmatic navigation, and route guards for authentication or authorization.

basic_examples.title: Setting up basic routes
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a router with two routes (`/` and `/about`) mapping to Vue components.

basic_examples.title: Using router in main app
basic_examples.explanation: Integrates Vue Router into the main Vue application.

basic_examples.title: Navigation links
basic_examples.code:
<template>
  <nav>
    <router-link to='/'>Home</router-link>
    <router-link to='/about'>About</router-link>
  </nav>
  <router-view></router-view>
</template>
basic_examples.explanation: Uses `<router-link>` for navigation and `<router-view>` to render the current route component.

advanced_examples.title: Dynamic route parameters
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a route with dynamic segments and accesses route parameters in a component.

advanced_examples.title: Nested routes
advanced_examples.explanation: Sets up nested routes inside a parent route.

advanced_examples.title: Navigation guards

advanced_examples.title: Programmatic navigation
advanced_examples.code:
<script setup>
import { useRouter } from 'vue-router';
const router = useRouter();
function goHome() {
  router.push('/');
}
</script>
<button @click="goHome">Go Home</button>
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates navigating programmatically using the `router.push()` method.

best_practices: Use `createWebHistory()` for clean URLs without hashes in production.
Keep route definitions modular and organize them in a separate router file.
Use nested routes for complex layouts with multiple sub-components.
Use meta fields to store route-specific information like authentication requirements.
Leverage navigation guards to protect sensitive routes.

error_handling.solution: Occurs when trying to navigate to the current route. Use `router.push()` with a catch or check if the route is different.
Add a wildcard route (`path: '/:pathMatch(.*)*'`) to display a NotFound component for unmatched URLs.
Ensure the route parameter is correctly defined and passed in the URL.

JavaScript.name: React Hook Form
JavaScript.description: React Hook Form is a performant, flexible, and easy-to-use library for managing forms in React. It leverages uncontrolled components and React hooks to reduce re-renders and improve form performance.
JavaScript.story: React Hook Form was created by Bill Luo to simplify form management in React applications. It focuses on minimizing boilerplate, reducing unnecessary re-renders, and providing easy integration with validation libraries like Yup and Zod.

usage.overview: React Hook Form uses the `useForm` hook to handle form state and validation. Inputs are registered via the `register` function, and submission is handled with `handleSubmit`. It supports synchronous and asynchronous validation, form resetting, error tracking, and custom input components.

basic_examples.title: Simple form with submit
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a basic form with two fields, registering them with `useForm` and logging the submitted data.

basic_examples.title: Form with validation
basic_examples.explanation: Adds simple required validation to a field and displays an error message if validation fails.

advanced_examples.title: Integrating with Yup validation
advanced_examples.explanation: Integrates React Hook Form with Yup schema validation for more complex rules.

advanced_examples.title: Custom input component
advanced_examples.code:
const CustomInput = ({ register, name }) => <input {...register(name)} />;
<CustomInput register={register} name='username' />
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates how to use custom input components with React Hook Form by forwarding the `register` function.

advanced_examples.title: Dynamic fields
advanced_examples.code:
const { fields, append, remove } = useFieldArray({ control, name: 'friends' });
fields.map((field, index) => <input {...register(`friends.${index}.name`)} />);
advanced_examples.explanation: Manages dynamic arrays of input fields with `useFieldArray`.

best_practices: Use uncontrolled components for better performance.
Leverage schema validation libraries like Yup or Zod for complex forms.
Use `useFieldArray` for dynamic fields.
Keep error messages user-friendly and accessible.
Reset forms using `reset()` when needed, especially after submission.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the input is registered with the `register` function and the name matches.
Check that `formState.errors` is being destructured from `useForm` and used properly in JSX.
Use `useFieldArray` with the `control` object and ensure proper indexing when mapping fields.

JavaScript.name: Formik
JavaScript.description: Formik is a popular React library for building and managing forms with ease. It simplifies form state management, validation, and submission handling while reducing boilerplate code.
JavaScript.story: Formik was created by Jared Palmer to address the complexity of handling forms in React applications. It provides a declarative API to manage form state, validation, and submission, integrating seamlessly with Yup for schema-based validation.

usage.overview: Formik provides a `useFormik` hook and `<Formik>` component to manage form state. It tracks values, errors, touched fields, and submission status. You can integrate with validation libraries like Yup and customize field components using `<Field>` or `useField`.

basic_examples.title: Simple form with useFormik
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a simple form that tracks a single email field and logs submitted values.

basic_examples.title: Using <Formik> component with render props
basic_examples.explanation: Demonstrates using the `<Formik>` component with `Form` and `Field` components for declarative form building.

advanced_examples.title: Form validation with Yup
advanced_examples.explanation: Integrates Yup schema validation with Formik to validate form fields.

advanced_examples.title: Custom input component using useField
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows how to create reusable custom input components with Formik’s `useField` hook.

advanced_examples.title: Handling multiple fields
advanced_examples.explanation: Manages multiple form fields in a single form using Formik.

best_practices: Use Yup for schema-based validation for cleaner and maintainable validation logic.
Leverage `useField` or `<Field>` for reusable custom input components.
Keep forms controlled via Formik to manage all state centrally.
Validate only on blur or submit to reduce unnecessary re-renders.
Use Formik context to access form state in deeply nested components.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the field is registered correctly with `name` attribute and connected via `useField` or `handleChange`.
Check that `validationSchema` is correctly passed and that error messages are rendered in JSX.
Make sure `onSubmit` is passed and the form element calls `handleSubmit`.

JavaScript.name: VeeValidate
JavaScript.description: VeeValidate is a form validation library for Vue.js that allows you to validate forms and inputs declaratively. It provides built-in validation rules, custom rules, and integrates seamlessly with Vue's reactivity system.
JavaScript.story: VeeValidate was created to simplify form validation in Vue applications by providing a declarative approach and reactive validation feedback. It supports both template-driven and composition API approaches, making it flexible for different Vue setups.

usage.overview: VeeValidate provides the `useForm` and `useField` composables (composition API) or `ValidationProvider` and `ValidationObserver` components (template API) to handle form validation. You can define rules, validate fields on input or blur, and display error messages reactively.

basic_examples.title: Basic usage with Composition API
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a field `email` with Yup validation. The form uses `handleSubmit` to handle submission.

basic_examples.title: Template API with ValidationProvider
basic_examples.code: {{ errors[0] }}
basic_examples.explanation: Uses the template API to validate an email input and show error messages.

advanced_examples.title: Custom validation rule
advanced_examples.code:
import { defineRule } from 'vee-validate';
defineRule('even', value => value % 2 === 0 || 'Value must be even');
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a custom validation rule called 'even' that checks if a number is even.

advanced_examples.title: Validating multiple fields
advanced_examples.code:
const { value: password } = useField('password', yup.string().min(6).required());
const { value: confirmPassword } = useField('confirmPassword', yup.string().oneOf([password], 'Passwords must match'));
advanced_examples.explanation: Validates password and confirm password fields, ensuring they match.

advanced_examples.title: Async validation
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates asynchronous validation for checking if an email is already in use.

best_practices: Prefer using the Composition API (`useForm` and `useField`) for new Vue 3 projects.
Use Yup or Zod schemas for complex validations.
Display error messages reactively next to input fields.
Use custom rules for business-specific validations.
Validate on blur or input to provide instant feedback.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the field is registered correctly and the rule is applied.
Check that you are accessing `errorMessage` (Composition API) or `errors` (Template API) in the template.
Make sure your rule function returns a promise and handles rejections properly.

JavaScript.name: Framer Motion
JavaScript.description: Framer Motion is a production-ready motion library for React that allows developers to create animations and interactive UI transitions easily, using a declarative API.
JavaScript.story: Framer Motion was created by the team behind Framer to provide a simple, yet powerful, way to animate React components. It leverages the power of the Framer library while being optimized for performance and accessibility, making complex animations achievable with minimal code.

usage.overview: Framer Motion uses components like `<motion.div>` and hooks such as `useAnimation` to animate React elements. It supports animations for position, scale, rotation, opacity, and more, along with gestures, layout transitions, keyframes, and variants for complex animation sequences.

basic_examples.title: Animate a div on mount
basic_examples.explanation: Animates a div from opacity 0 to 1 over 1 second when the component mounts.

basic_examples.title: Hover animation
basic_examples.code:
<motion.button whileHover={{ scale: 1.2 }}>
  Hover me!
</motion.button>
basic_examples.explanation: Scales the button up when hovered.

advanced_examples.title: Using variants for complex animations
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines reusable animation states (variants) for a component and transitions between them.

advanced_examples.title: Gestures with drag
advanced_examples.code:
<motion.div drag dragConstraints={{ left: 0, right: 100, top: 0, bottom: 100 }}>
  Drag me!
</motion.div>
advanced_examples.explanation: Allows the user to drag the element within specified constraints.

advanced_examples.title: Animating layout changes
advanced_examples.code:
<motion.div layout>
  {items.map(item => (
    <motion.div key={item.id} layout>{item.name}</motion.div>
  ))}
</motion.div>
advanced_examples.explanation: Animates the position of items automatically when the layout changes.

advanced_examples.title: Keyframes animation
advanced_examples.code: <motion.div animate={{ x: [0, 100, 50, 100, 0] }} transition={{ duration: 2 }} />
advanced_examples.explanation: Animates the element along multiple positions sequentially using keyframes.

best_practices: Use variants to manage multiple animation states efficiently.
Prefer `layout` prop for automatic layout animations on reordering components.
Use `transition` properties to control timing and easing for smoother animations.
Leverage gesture props like `whileHover`, `whileTap`, and `drag` for interactive UIs.
Keep performance in mind: avoid animating large numbers of elements unnecessarily.

error_handling.solution: Ensure that you are using `<motion.div>` (or other motion elements) and that `initial` and `animate` props are correctly set.
Use the `layout` prop consistently and avoid conflicting CSS transforms.
Consider using `AnimatePresence` for conditional components and limit simultaneous animations.

JavaScript.name: GSAP
JavaScript.description: GSAP (GreenSock Animation Platform) is a powerful JavaScript library for creating high-performance animations on the web. It supports complex sequencing, tweening, and timeline-based animations with smooth performance across all major browsers.
JavaScript.story: GSAP was created by Jack Doyle (GreenSock) in the mid-2000s to provide a professional-grade animation library that works consistently across browsers. It has become widely adopted in web development for animations ranging from simple UI transitions to complex interactive motion graphics.

usage.overview: GSAP provides `gsap.to()`, `gsap.from()`, `gsap.fromTo()`, and `gsap.timeline()` methods to animate DOM elements, canvas, SVG, and more. Animations can be chained, sequenced, and controlled with easing, duration, delays, and callbacks.

basic_examples.title: Simple tween
basic_examples.code:
import { gsap } from 'gsap';
gsap.to('.box', { x: 100, duration: 1 });
basic_examples.explanation: Animates the element with class `box` 100px to the right over 1 second.

basic_examples.title: Tween from initial state
basic_examples.code: gsap.from('.box', { opacity: 0, y: -50, duration: 1 });
basic_examples.explanation: Animates the element from opacity 0 and y-position -50px to its current state.

advanced_examples.title: Timeline sequencing
advanced_examples.explanation: Creates a timeline to sequence multiple animations with repeat and yoyo effects.

advanced_examples.title: Animating multiple elements
advanced_examples.code: gsap.to('.box', { x: 200, stagger: 0.2, duration: 1 });
advanced_examples.explanation: Animates multiple elements with the `box` class, staggering their start times by 0.2 seconds.

advanced_examples.title: Scroll-triggered animation
advanced_examples.explanation: Animates an element based on scroll position using the ScrollTrigger plugin.

advanced_examples.title: SVG animation
advanced_examples.code: gsap.to('#circle', { strokeDashoffset: 0, duration: 2 });
advanced_examples.explanation: Animates an SVG circle’s stroke using strokeDashoffset for a drawing effect.

best_practices: Use timelines for sequencing multiple animations to maintain control and readability.
Use hardware-accelerated properties like transforms for smoother animations.
Leverage GSAP plugins (ScrollTrigger, Draggable, MotionPathPlugin) for advanced interactivity.
Keep animations performant by limiting unnecessary DOM manipulations.
Use easing functions to create natural motion.

error_handling.solution: Ensure GSAP is imported correctly, e.g., `import { gsap } from 'gsap';` or included via CDN.
Ensure the DOM element exists and is accessible before animating it.
For GSAP plugins, make sure to import and register them, e.g., `gsap.registerPlugin(ScrollTrigger);`

JavaScript.name: Anime.js
JavaScript.description: Anime.js is a lightweight JavaScript animation library that works with CSS properties, SVG, DOM attributes, and JavaScript objects. It enables creating smooth, powerful, and complex animations with a simple API.
JavaScript.story: Anime.js was created by Julian Garnier to provide developers a flexible and easy-to-use library for performing animations on the web. It supports timeline-based animations, staggering, easing, and complex sequences, making it a popular choice for interactive UI and motion graphics.

usage.overview: Anime.js provides the `anime()` function to animate properties of HTML, SVG, or JS objects. You can define targets, properties, duration, easing, delay, loops, direction, and callbacks. It also supports timelines for sequencing multiple animations.

basic_examples.title: Animate a div's position
basic_examples.explanation: Animates an element with class `box` 250px to the right over 1 second with ease-in-out easing.

basic_examples.title: Animate multiple properties
basic_examples.explanation: Simultaneously animates translation, rotation, and scale of an element.

advanced_examples.title: Using timeline for sequencing
advanced_examples.explanation: Creates a timeline to chain multiple animations in sequence with consistent easing and duration.

advanced_examples.title: Staggered animation
advanced_examples.explanation: Animates multiple elements with a staggered delay between each animation.

advanced_examples.title: Animating SVG properties
advanced_examples.explanation: Animates an SVG circle's strokeDashoffset to create a drawing effect.

advanced_examples.title: Looping and direction
advanced_examples.explanation: Animates an element back and forth indefinitely using looping and alternate direction.

best_practices: Use timelines to manage complex sequences cleanly.
Prefer CSS transforms over top/left for better performance.
Use easing functions for natural motion.
Stagger animations to add depth and rhythm to UI elements.
Use callbacks (`begin`, `update`, `complete`) for custom logic during animations.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the target element exists and is not hidden or removed from DOM.
Verify that the property is animatable and correctly spelled.
Check that each timeline step has a valid target and that the timeline is properly constructed.

JavaScript.name: Axios
JavaScript.description: Axios is a promise-based HTTP client for JavaScript that works in both the browser and Node.js. It simplifies making HTTP requests, handling responses, and managing errors.
JavaScript.story: Axios was created to provide a simpler and more consistent API for making HTTP requests in JavaScript compared to the built-in `fetch` API. It supports request and response interception, automatic JSON transformation, and is widely adopted in both front-end and back-end JavaScript projects.

usage.overview: Axios allows you to perform HTTP requests using methods such as GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, and more. It returns promises that resolve with response objects containing data, status, headers, and config. Axios also supports request cancellation, interceptors, and timeout configuration.

basic_examples.title: GET request
basic_examples.explanation: Performs a GET request to the given URL and logs the response data.

basic_examples.title: POST request with JSON payload
basic_examples.explanation: Sends a POST request with a JSON payload and logs the returned data.

advanced_examples.title: Setting custom headers
advanced_examples.explanation: Adds custom headers to a request, useful for authentication or custom API requirements.

advanced_examples.title: Using interceptors
advanced_examples.explanation: Intercepts requests and responses globally for logging, modifying headers, or handling errors.

advanced_examples.title: Canceling requests
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates canceling a request using Axios CancelToken.

advanced_examples.title: Concurrent requests
advanced_examples.explanation: Performs multiple HTTP requests concurrently and handles the responses together.

best_practices: Use interceptors for handling authentication, logging, or error processing.
Always catch errors and handle them gracefully.
Use environment variables for base URLs and API tokens.
Leverage request cancellation to avoid race conditions or unnecessary network calls.
Use async/await syntax for cleaner asynchronous code.

error_handling.solution: Check your internet connection or the API endpoint availability.
Set a reasonable timeout using `axios({ timeout: 5000 })` and handle cases where the request takes too long.
Use `error.response` to inspect status codes and messages, and handle specific status codes appropriately.

JavaScript.name: SWR
JavaScript.description: SWR (stale-while-revalidate) is a React Hooks library for data fetching that provides caching, revalidation, focus tracking, and automatic retries. It simplifies fetching remote data and keeps UI in sync with the latest data.
JavaScript.story: SWR was created by the Vercel team to offer a simple, efficient, and declarative way to fetch data in React applications. Inspired by HTTP cache strategies, SWR focuses on returning cached data first, then revalidating in the background, providing both speed and freshness.

usage.overview: SWR uses the `useSWR` hook to fetch data. You pass a key (usually the API URL) and a fetcher function. It returns data, error, and status, while automatically handling caching, revalidation, and retries.

basic_examples.title: Simple GET request
basic_examples.explanation: Uses `useSWR` to fetch user data from `/api/user`, showing loading, error, and fetched states.

advanced_examples.title: Polling / Revalidation Interval
advanced_examples.code: const { data } = useSWR('/api/todos', fetcher, { refreshInterval: 5000 });
advanced_examples.explanation: Automatically re-fetches data every 5 seconds to keep UI updated.

advanced_examples.title: Conditional Fetching
advanced_examples.code: const { data } = useSWR(userId ? `/api/user/${userId}` : null, fetcher);
advanced_examples.explanation: Fetches data only if `userId` exists; otherwise, disables the request.

advanced_examples.title: Error Retry and Deduplication
advanced_examples.explanation: Retries failed requests up to 3 times with a 5-second delay between retries.

advanced_examples.title: Mutating Data / Optimistic Updates
advanced_examples.explanation: Updates cached data optimistically before sending the actual request and then revalidates.

best_practices: Use `fetcher` functions consistently across your app for caching benefits.
Combine SWR with React Suspense for better loading handling.
Leverage `mutate` for optimistic UI updates.
Use `dedupingInterval` to prevent duplicate requests.
Use error retries and revalidation for robust data fetching.

error_handling.solution: Handle errors using the `error` object returned by `useSWR` and optionally retry requests.
Use `mutate` or `refreshInterval` to ensure the UI revalidates and updates cached data.
Ensure conditional keys are used to prevent fetching with undefined/null values.

JavaScript.name: React Query
JavaScript.description: React Query is a powerful data-fetching library for React that simplifies fetching, caching, synchronizing, and updating server state in your React applications.
JavaScript.story: React Query was created by Tanner Linsley to solve common challenges in managing server state in React apps, such as caching, background updates, and synchronization. It allows developers to focus on building UI while React Query manages the complexity of data fetching and caching efficiently.

usage.overview: React Query provides hooks like `useQuery`, `useMutation`, and `useInfiniteQuery` to fetch and mutate data. It handles caching, background refetching, pagination, and stale data management automatically.

basic_examples.title: Fetching data with useQuery
basic_examples.explanation: Fetches a list of todos from an API and automatically manages loading, error, and cached states.

advanced_examples.title: Mutating data with useMutation
advanced_examples.explanation: Adds a new todo item and invalidates the todos query to refresh cached data.

advanced_examples.title: Paginated queries
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates fetching data in pages and automatically handling pagination using `useInfiniteQuery`.

advanced_examples.title: Query invalidation
advanced_examples.code:
const queryClient = useQueryClient();
queryClient.invalidateQueries(['todos']);
advanced_examples.explanation: Manually invalidates cached queries to refetch fresh data from the server.

advanced_examples.title: Prefetching data
advanced_examples.code: queryClient.prefetchQuery(['todos'], fetchTodos);
advanced_examples.explanation: Prefetches data in the background so it is ready when a component mounts.

best_practices: Use `useQuery` for fetching data and `useMutation` for modifying data.
Leverage query keys for caching and invalidation granularity.
Use `staleTime` and `cacheTime` wisely to balance performance and freshness.
Prefetch data when possible for faster UI transitions.
Combine with `useQueryClient` for advanced cache manipulation and query invalidation.

error_handling.solution: Handle errors using the `error` property returned by `useQuery` or `useMutation` and provide fallback UI.
Adjust `staleTime` to control when data is considered fresh and triggers background refetch.
Ensure to invalidate relevant queries using `queryClient.invalidateQueries` after successful mutations.

JavaScript.name: Lodash
JavaScript.description: Lodash is a modern JavaScript utility library delivering modularity, performance, and extras. It provides tools for working with arrays, objects, strings, functions, and more, simplifying common programming tasks.
JavaScript.story: Lodash was created by John-David Dalton to offer a more consistent and performant alternative to native JavaScript utilities. It has become widely adopted due to its convenience, extensive documentation, and functional programming utilities.

usage.overview: Lodash provides hundreds of utility functions for data manipulation, functional programming, and performance optimization. Functions are available for arrays, objects, strings, numbers, and more.

basic_examples.title: Using _.chunk
basic_examples.explanation: Splits an array into chunks of the specified size.

basic_examples.title: Using _.merge
basic_examples.explanation: Deep merges two objects together.

advanced_examples.title: Debounce function
advanced_examples.explanation: Creates a debounced function that delays invoking `log` until after 1 second has elapsed since the last call.

advanced_examples.title: Throttle function
advanced_examples.explanation: Creates a throttled function that invokes `log` at most once every 2 seconds.

advanced_examples.title: Cloning objects
advanced_examples.explanation: Performs a deep clone of an object.

advanced_examples.title: Chaining methods
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates chaining multiple Lodash methods to transform data.

best_practices: Import only the functions you need to reduce bundle size.
Use chaining (`_()`) for readable sequences of operations.
Use debouncing and throttling for performance-sensitive event handlers.
Prefer Lodash for deep cloning or merging objects instead of manual implementations.
Leverage utility functions for safer and cleaner data manipulation.

error_handling.solution: Ensure input objects or arrays are not undefined before using Lodash methods.
Use `_.merge` for deep merge and `_.assign` for shallow merge based on the requirement.

JavaScript.name: date-fns
JavaScript.description: date-fns is a modern JavaScript library that provides comprehensive, lightweight, and modular functions for parsing, formatting, manipulating, and comparing dates.
JavaScript.story: date-fns was created to provide a functional, immutable, and tree-shakable alternative to libraries like Moment.js. Each function in date-fns is independent, allowing developers to import only what they need, resulting in smaller bundle sizes and better performance.

usage.overview: date-fns provides over 200 functions for working with dates, including formatting, parsing, difference calculations, comparisons, adding or subtracting time, and more. Functions are pure and immutable, returning new date objects rather than modifying existing ones.

basic_examples.title: Formatting a date
basic_examples.explanation: Formats a Date object to a string with the specified pattern.

basic_examples.title: Parsing a date string
basic_examples.explanation: Parses a date string according to a given format into a Date object.

advanced_examples.title: Adding and subtracting time
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates adding days or subtracting months from a date.

advanced_examples.title: Difference between dates
advanced_examples.explanation: Calculates the number of days between two dates.

advanced_examples.title: Comparing dates
advanced_examples.explanation: Checks if one date is before or after another.

advanced_examples.title: Start and end of time units
advanced_examples.explanation: Gets the start and end dates of a month.

best_practices: Import only the functions you need to reduce bundle size (tree-shaking).
Use pure functions to avoid mutating original Date objects.
Always provide a fallback Date for parsing when using `parse`.
Use UTC functions when working across time zones to avoid inconsistencies.
Combine with other date-fns utilities for cleaner and more readable date manipulations.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the input is a valid Date object or properly formatted string. Use `isValid(date)` to check before processing.
Ensure the string matches the format exactly when using `parse()`.

JavaScript.name: Moment.js
JavaScript.description: Moment.js is a widely-used JavaScript library for parsing, validating, manipulating, and formatting dates and times. It simplifies working with dates across different browsers and time zones.
JavaScript.story: Moment.js was created to provide a robust, reliable, and easy-to-use API for date manipulation in JavaScript. It became popular due to inconsistencies in the native Date object and its lack of convenient formatting, parsing, and timezone handling capabilities.

usage.overview: Moment.js allows you to create, parse, manipulate, and format dates and times easily. You can chain multiple operations, handle relative times, perform comparisons, and work with time zones using Moment Timezone.

basic_examples.title: Getting current date and formatting
basic_examples.explanation: Creates a Moment object representing the current date and time, then formats it as a string.

basic_examples.title: Parsing a date string
basic_examples.code:
const date = moment('2025-08-22', 'YYYY-MM-DD');
console.log(date.format('MMMM Do, YYYY'));
basic_examples.explanation: Parses a date string using a specified format and formats it in a human-readable form.

advanced_examples.title: Manipulating dates
advanced_examples.code:
let future = moment().add(7, 'days').subtract(2, 'hours');
console.log(future.format());
advanced_examples.explanation: Adds 7 days and subtracts 2 hours from the current date.

advanced_examples.title: Comparing dates
advanced_examples.explanation: Compares two Moment objects to determine their chronological order.

advanced_examples.title: Relative time
advanced_examples.code:
const past = moment('2025-08-15');
console.log(past.fromNow());
advanced_examples.explanation: Displays the relative time from now, e.g., '7 days ago'.

advanced_examples.title: Timezone handling
advanced_examples.explanation: Creates a Moment object in a specific timezone using Moment Timezone.

best_practices: Use `.clone()` before modifying dates to avoid mutating original Moment objects.
Prefer ISO 8601 strings for parsing to ensure consistency.
Use Moment Timezone when working with different time zones.
Use relative time functions for user-friendly date displays.
Be aware that Moment.js is in maintenance mode; consider alternatives like date-fns or Luxon for new projects.

error_handling.solution: Ensure that the input string matches the expected format or use Moment's strict parsing mode.
Use Moment.js instead of relying solely on the native Date object to handle inconsistencies.

JavaScript.name: Day.js
JavaScript.description: Day.js is a minimalist JavaScript library for parsing, validating, manipulating, and formatting dates. It provides a modern API similar to Moment.js but with a much smaller footprint.
JavaScript.story: Day.js was created to provide a lightweight alternative to Moment.js while maintaining a familiar API. Its modular architecture allows importing only the features you need, reducing bundle size significantly for web applications.

usage.overview: Day.js offers simple functions for working with dates, including parsing, formatting, adding or subtracting time, comparing dates, and working with relative times or durations.

basic_examples.title: Getting current date and formatting
basic_examples.explanation: Gets the current date and formats it as a string.

basic_examples.title: Parsing a date string
basic_examples.code:
const date = dayjs('2025-08-22');
console.log(date.format('MMMM D, YYYY'));
basic_examples.explanation: Parses a string into a Day.js object and formats it.

advanced_examples.title: Adding and subtracting time
advanced_examples.code:
const future = dayjs().add(7, 'day').subtract(2, 'hour');
console.log(future.format());
advanced_examples.explanation: Adds 7 days and subtracts 2 hours from the current date.

advanced_examples.title: Comparing dates
advanced_examples.explanation: Compares two dates to check if one is before or after the other.

advanced_examples.title: Relative time
advanced_examples.explanation: Displays relative time from now, e.g., '7 days ago', using the relativeTime plugin.

advanced_examples.title: Working with UTC
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses the UTC plugin to handle dates in Coordinated Universal Time.

best_practices: Use plugins only for features you need to minimize bundle size.
Prefer Day.js for modern JavaScript projects requiring small date libraries.
Use immutable objects to avoid unintended mutations.
Use ISO 8601 strings when possible for consistent parsing.
Combine with timezone plugins for handling different time zones.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the input string is in a valid format or use `dayjs(string, format)` with the correct format specified.
Extend Day.js with required plugins before using their functions, e.g., `dayjs.extend(plugin)`.

JavaScript.name: Ramda
JavaScript.description: Ramda is a practical functional library for JavaScript programmers. It provides a suite of utility functions for functional programming, emphasizing immutability, currying, and composition.
JavaScript.story: Ramda was created to help developers write cleaner and more maintainable code using functional programming principles. Unlike other utility libraries, Ramda's functions are automatically curried and designed to be data-last, making composition simple and intuitive.

usage.overview: Ramda provides functions for working with arrays, objects, strings, and functions in a functional style. Its utilities support currying, composition, and point-free programming.

basic_examples.title: Mapping over an array
basic_examples.explanation: Uses `R.map` to apply a function to each element in an array.

basic_examples.title: Filtering an array
basic_examples.explanation: Filters elements of an array that satisfy the provided predicate function.

advanced_examples.title: Function composition
advanced_examples.explanation: Composes functions so that `add1` runs first and `double` runs on its result.

advanced_examples.title: Currying
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates Ramda’s automatic currying of functions for partial application.

advanced_examples.title: Deep object manipulation
advanced_examples.explanation: Updates a nested property immutably using `assocPath`.

advanced_examples.title: Lens usage
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses Ramda lenses to focus on and update nested data in an immutable way.

best_practices: Use point-free style and function composition for cleaner code.
Favor immutability and avoid mutating input data.
Leverage currying and partial application to simplify reusable functions.
Use lenses for safe manipulation of nested objects.
Combine Ramda functions with native JavaScript for optimal performance and readability.

error_handling.error: TypeError: value.map is not a function
error_handling.solution: Ensure the input to array functions like `R.map` or `R.filter` is actually an array.
Make sure you use `R.set` to update values and `R.view` to read, since Ramda functions are immutable.

JavaScript.name: Jest
JavaScript.description: Jest is a delightful JavaScript testing framework with a focus on simplicity, correctness, and developer experience. It supports unit, integration, and snapshot testing for JavaScript and TypeScript projects.
JavaScript.story: Jest was created by Facebook to test React applications, but it has grown to support any JavaScript project. Its zero-configuration setup, powerful mocking capabilities, and snapshot testing features make it widely popular for testing modern web applications.

usage.overview: Jest allows developers to write tests using simple syntax and run them in a fast and isolated environment. It supports features like mocks, spies, snapshot testing, code coverage, and parallel test execution.

basic_examples.title: Basic test example
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a simple unit test that verifies the sum function returns the correct result.

basic_examples.title: Using beforeEach
basic_examples.explanation: Resets the counter before each test using `beforeEach`.

advanced_examples.title: Mocking functions
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates using Jest's `fn()` to create a mock function and assert it was called with specific arguments.

advanced_examples.title: Snapshot testing
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses snapshot testing to verify that the object structure does not change unexpectedly.

advanced_examples.title: Testing asynchronous code
advanced_examples.explanation: Tests an asynchronous function using `async/await` syntax.

advanced_examples.title: Mocking modules
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows how to mock entire modules to control dependencies in tests.

best_practices: Write small, focused tests for individual units of code.
Use mocks and spies to isolate the code under test.
Leverage snapshot testing for UI components and serializable objects.
Run tests in watch mode during development for faster feedback.
Organize test files alongside source files or in a __tests__ directory for clarity.

error_handling.error: Test failed due to unexpected value
error_handling.solution: Check the expected value, and ensure the function under test produces consistent outputs.
Verify module paths and use `jest.mock()` appropriately when mocking dependencies.

error_handling.error: Timeout - Async callback was not invoked
error_handling.solution: Ensure asynchronous tests call `done()` or return a promise, and adjust timeout if necessary.

JavaScript.name: Vitest
JavaScript.description: Vitest is a blazing fast unit testing framework for Vite projects, designed to be highly compatible with Jest. It supports TypeScript out-of-the-box, snapshots, mocks, and a rich API for testing modern JavaScript and TypeScript applications.
JavaScript.story: Vitest was created to provide a fast, modern testing solution tightly integrated with Vite's development environment. Its zero-config setup and Vite-native execution allow instant feedback during development, making it ideal for frontend projects with hot module replacement.

usage.overview: Vitest allows developers to write tests using a syntax similar to Jest, including `describe`, `it/test`, `expect`, and supports mocking, snapshots, and parallel execution. It integrates with Vite for fast startup and hot-reload support.

basic_examples.title: Simple test example
basic_examples.explanation: Defines a simple test suite and test case that verifies a sum function returns the correct result.

basic_examples.title: Async test example
basic_examples.explanation: Tests an asynchronous function and ensures it resolves to the expected value.

advanced_examples.title: Mocking functions
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates creating a mock function and asserting it was called with specific arguments.

advanced_examples.title: Snapshot testing
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses snapshot testing to verify that an object structure does not change unexpectedly.

advanced_examples.title: Testing modules with mocks
advanced_examples.explanation: Shows how to mock an imported module and control its behavior during tests.

advanced_examples.title: Using beforeEach and afterEach
advanced_examples.explanation: Demonstrates setup and teardown hooks in Vitest tests.

best_practices: Use Vitest's Vite integration for instant test feedback.
Leverage mocks and spies to isolate unit tests.
Use snapshot testing for UI components or structured objects.
Organize test files logically alongside source files or in a `tests` folder.
Run tests in watch mode during development for fast feedback loops.

error_handling.solution: Check the expected values and ensure mocks are correctly configured.
Ensure asynchronous operations are awaited or return promises from test callbacks.
Verify that Vite's module resolution is correctly set up and paths are valid.

JavaScript.name: Cypress
JavaScript.description: Cypress is a next-generation front-end testing tool built for the modern web. It allows developers to write end-to-end, integration, and unit tests for web applications with fast, reliable, and easy-to-debug tests.
JavaScript.story: Cypress was created to improve the developer experience for testing web applications. Unlike traditional Selenium-based tools, Cypress runs in the same run-loop as the application, providing faster execution, automatic waiting, and real-time reloads. It is particularly popular for testing React, Vue, Angular, and other modern frontend frameworks.

usage.overview: Cypress allows you to write tests in JavaScript using a simple, readable syntax. It provides automatic waiting for commands, real-time reloads, time-travel debugging, and screenshots or video recording of test runs.

basic_examples.title: Visiting a page and checking content
basic_examples.explanation: Opens a webpage, clicks on a link containing the text 'type', and asserts that the URL includes '/commands/actions'.

basic_examples.title: Typing into an input field
basic_examples.explanation: Finds an input element, types a value, and asserts that the input contains the expected value.

advanced_examples.title: Intercepting network requests
advanced_examples.code:
cy.intercept('GET', '/users', { fixture: 'users.json' }).as('getUsers')
cy.visit('/users')
cy.wait('@getUsers')
advanced_examples.explanation: Mocks a GET request to '/users' with a fixture and waits for the request to complete.

advanced_examples.title: Custom commands
advanced_examples.explanation: Defines a reusable custom command for logging in.

advanced_examples.title: Handling file uploads
advanced_examples.code: cy.get('input[type=file]').attachFile('example.json')
advanced_examples.explanation: Uses the Cypress file upload plugin to attach a file to an input element.

advanced_examples.title: Assertions with chai
advanced_examples.code: cy.get('.todo-list li').should('have.length', 3).and('contain', 'Buy milk')
advanced_examples.explanation: Performs multiple assertions on selected elements using Cypress + Chai syntax.

best_practices: Use `.as()` and `cy.wait()` to manage network requests reliably.
Leverage custom commands for reusable actions to simplify tests.
Keep tests isolated and independent for consistent results.
Use fixtures for consistent test data.
Run Cypress in CI environments using headless mode for automated pipelines.

error_handling.solution: Ensure the element exists before interacting. Use `cy.get()` with `{ timeout: <ms> }` if needed.
Ensure the element is stable before asserting or interacting. Cypress automatically retries, but sometimes waiting for network or animations helps.
Check network availability, server response, or use `cy.intercept()` to mock the request.

JavaScript.name: Playwright
JavaScript.description: Playwright is a Node.js library for browser automation that enables reliable end-to-end testing across Chromium, Firefox, and WebKit with a single API. It supports modern web app features like single-page applications and multi-page flows.
JavaScript.story: Playwright was created by Microsoft to provide fast, reliable, and cross-browser automation for testing web applications. It aims to overcome the limitations of older tools like Selenium by providing automatic waiting, rich selectors, network interception, and built-in support for modern web features.

usage.overview: Playwright allows you to automate browser interactions for testing purposes, including navigation, clicking, typing, taking screenshots, capturing videos, and handling multiple pages or contexts. It provides APIs for synchronous-like control and automatic waiting.

basic_examples.title: Launching a browser and visiting a page
basic_examples.explanation: Launches a Chromium browser, opens a new page, navigates to a URL, and closes the browser.

basic_examples.title: Clicking and typing

Leverage automatic waiting to reduce flakiness in tests.
Run tests in headless mode in CI/CD pipelines for speed.
Use browser contexts to isolate tests and avoid state sharing.
Take screenshots or videos for debugging failed tests.

error_handling.solution: Increase the timeout or ensure the element exists before interacting.
Use robust selectors and consider using `page.waitForSelector` to wait for elements.
Ensure Playwright browsers are installed (`npx playwright install`) and dependencies are met.

JavaScript.name: Vite
JavaScript.description: Vite is a modern frontend build tool that provides a fast development server and optimized build process for modern web projects. It leverages native ES modules in the browser and bundles with Rollup for production.
JavaScript.story: Vite was created by Evan You (the creator of Vue.js) to improve the frontend development experience by offering instant server start, fast hot module replacement (HMR), and an optimized build output. It supports frameworks like Vue, React, Svelte, and vanilla JavaScript projects.

usage.overview: Vite provides a development server with native ES module support and lightning-fast hot module replacement. For production builds, it uses Rollup to bundle and optimize assets. It supports plugins, TypeScript, JSX, CSS preprocessors, and framework-specific configurations.

Take advantage of Vite's HMR during development for instant feedback.
Use plugins for framework-specific features and optimizations.
Keep configuration minimal; Vite works with zero-config for many projects.
Use environment variables and .env files to manage project settings.

Ensure file paths are correct and modules are installed via npm/yarn.
Check that the browser supports ES modules and clear the cache. Ensure the project uses supported frameworks/plugins.

JavaScript.name: Webpack
JavaScript.description: Webpack is a powerful and flexible module bundler for JavaScript applications. It takes modules with dependencies and generates static assets representing those modules for the browser.
JavaScript.story: Webpack was created by Tobias Koppers in 2012 to manage complex front-end projects with multiple dependencies. It became popular for its ability to bundle JavaScript files along with CSS, images, and other assets, supporting features like code splitting, tree shaking, and hot module replacement.

usage.overview: Webpack allows you to define entry points, output bundles, loaders to process files (like Babel for JS or CSS loaders), and plugins for extended functionality. It is widely used to optimize, bundle, and manage dependencies for modern web applications.

Use plugins for repetitive tasks and to extend Webpack functionality.
Enable code splitting and tree shaking to reduce bundle size.
Keep configuration modular and maintainable for larger projects.

JavaScript.name: Rollup
JavaScript.description: Rollup is a JavaScript module bundler that compiles small pieces of code into something larger and more complex, such as a library or application. It uses ES modules to produce optimized, tree-shaken bundles.
JavaScript.story: Rollup was created to take advantage of ES module syntax in JavaScript and provide a more efficient bundling process compared to older tools. It became popular for bundling libraries because of its ability to generate clean, minimal output with tree-shaking to remove unused code.

usage.overview: Rollup takes ES module files as input, resolves dependencies, and outputs a single JavaScript file. It supports plugins for handling non-JS files, Babel transpilation, and other transformations. Rollup is particularly good for building libraries that are shared across projects.

advanced_examples.explanation: Integrates Babel with Rollup to transpile modern JavaScript for compatibility with older environments.

advanced_examples.title: Tree-shaking example
advanced_examples.explanation: Rollup removes unused exports automatically to reduce bundle size.

advanced_examples.title: Multiple output formats

best_practices: Use ES modules for cleaner and more tree-shakable code.
Leverage plugins for handling non-JS assets, transpilation, and optimizations.
Keep Rollup configuration modular and reusable.
Use multiple output formats for library distribution (CJS, ESM, UMD).
Enable source maps during development for easier debugging.

error_handling.solution: Check file paths and use appropriate plugins like `@rollup/plugin-node-resolve` for node_modules imports.
Use plugins like `@rollup/plugin-json` to import JSON files.
Ensure tree-shaking works correctly and consider splitting code into multiple chunks using dynamic imports.

JavaScript.name: Parcel
JavaScript.description: Parcel is a fast, zero-configuration web application bundler. It supports JavaScript, TypeScript, CSS, HTML, images, and more out of the box without requiring a complex configuration.
JavaScript.story: Parcel was created by Devon Govett to provide an easier and faster alternative to Webpack. It focuses on simplicity and speed, using worker processes for parallel compilation, automatic dependency resolution, and built-in support for modern web standards.

usage.overview: Parcel automatically detects the entry point of your project and builds an optimized bundle. It supports hot module replacement, code splitting, tree-shaking, and integrates well with modern frontend frameworks like React, Vue, and Svelte.

# Build for production
npm run build
basic_examples.explanation: Starts a development server with HMR and builds a production bundle for deployment.

Use dynamic imports for code splitting and faster page load.
Monitor build output to ensure bundle size is optimized.
